1. Introduction

1. Linear geometry

  • Definition 2.1. Let V,WV,WV,W be real vector spaces; a linear map is a function T:V→WT : V \to WT:V→W s.t. for all v,w∈Vv,w \in Vv,w∈V and a,b∈Ra,b \in \Ra,b∈R,
    T(av+bw)=aT(v)+bT(w)T(av + bw) = aT(v) + bT(w)T(av+bw)=aT(v)+bT(w)
    • The set of linear maps T:V→WT : V \to WT:V→W is Hom⁡(V,W)\operatorname{Hom}(V,W)Hom(V,W)
    • If the matrix for TTT is AAA, write T=TAT = T_AT=TA​ or LAL_ALA​
  • Exercise 9. For any A∈Mm×n(R)A \in M_{m \times n}(\R)A∈Mm×n​(R), Aei=CiAe_i = C_iAei​=Ci​, the iiith column of AAA
    • So for v=(v1,…,vn)∈Rnv = (v_1,\dotsc,v_n) \in \R^nv=(v1​,…,vn​)∈Rn, Av=v1C1+⋯+vnCnAv = v_1C_1 + \dotsb + v_nC_nAv=v1​C1​+⋯+vn​Cn​
  • Proposition 2.5. The map Φ:Mm×n(R)→Hom⁡(Rn,Rm)\Phi : M_{m \times n}(\R) \to \operatorname{Hom}(\R^n,\R^m)Φ:Mm×n​(R)→Hom(Rn,Rm), A↦TAA \mapsto T_AA↦TA​ is a linear isomorphism
  • Proposition 2.6. The image of TAT_ATA​ is the column space C(A)C(A)C(A) of AAA
  • Proposition 2.7. The dimension of the image of TAT_ATA​ is the rank of AAA
  • Proposition 2.10. For v,w∈Rnv,w \in \R^nv,w∈Rn, TA(v)=TA(w)T_A(v) = T_A(w)TA​(v)=TA​(w) iff v−w∈ker⁡TA=N(A)v - w \in \ker T_A = N(A)v−w∈kerTA​=N(A)
  • Theorem 2.13. Let AAA be an n×nn \times nn×n matrix with column vectors C1,…,Cn∈RnC_1,\dotsc,C_n \in \R^nC1​,…,Cn​∈Rn; then det⁡A\det AdetA is the signed nnn-dimensional volume of the parallelepiped spanned by C1,…,CnC_1,\dotsc,C_nC1​,…,Cn​ (i.e. area expansion)
    • Parallelepiped spanned by v1,…,vn={a1v1+⋯+anvn:0≤a1,…,an≤1}v_1,\dotsc,v_n = \{a_1v_1 + \dotsb + a_nv_n : 0 \leq a_1,\dotsc,a_n \leq 1\}v1​,…,vn​={a1​v1​+⋯+an​vn​:0≤a1​,…,an​≤1}
  • Theorem 2.16. Let A∈Mn(R)A \in M_n(\R)A∈Mn​(R) and S⊆RnS \subseteq \R^nS⊆Rn with nnn-dimensional volume VVV
    • (i) TA:Rn→RnT_A : \R^n \to \R^nTA​:Rn→Rn preserves (resp. reverses) orientation iff det⁡A>0\det A > 0detA>0 (resp det⁡A<0\det A < 0detA<0)
    • (ii) TA(S)T_A(S)TA​(S) has nnn-dimensional volume V∣det⁡A∣V\abs{\det A}V∣detA∣
  • Proposition 2.17. For an n×nn \times nn×n matrix AAA, det⁡A=0\det A = 0detA=0 iff ker⁡TA\ker T_AkerTA​ is nontrivial (i.e. nonzero nullity)
  • Proposition 2.18. AAA is invertible iff det⁡A≠0\det A \neq 0detA=0

Eigenstuff and change of basis

  • Matrix w.r.t. bases: if e,fe,fe,f are bases for V,WV,WV,W, then matrix of TTT w.r.t. e,fe,fe,f is s.t. (Te,f)ij=aij(T_{e,f})_{ij} = a_{ij}(Te,f​)ij​=aij​ where T(ej)=a1jf1+⋯+amjfmT(e_j) = a_{1j}f_1 + \dotsb + a_{mj}f_mT(ej​)=a1j​f1​+⋯+amj​fm​
    • When V=WV = WV=W, can take e=fe = fe=f, and write Te=Te,eT_e = T_{e,e}Te​=Te,e​
    • If T:U→VT : U \to VT:U→V and T′:V→WT' : V \to WT′:V→W are linear with bases e,f,ge,f,ge,f,g for U,V,WU,V,WU,V,W, then matrix of T′∘TT' \circ TT′∘T w.r.t. e,ge,ge,g is (T′∘T)e,g=Tf,g′Te,f(T' \circ T)_{e,g} = T'_{f,g} T_{e,f}(T′∘T)e,g​=Tf,g′​Te,f​
  • Change of basis matrix: if e,fe,fe,f are bases of Rn\R^nRn, the change of basis matrix Me→fM_{e \to f}Me→f​ is the matrix of the identity map w.r.t. e,fe,fe,f
    • Me→fMf→e=I=Mf→eMe→fM_{e \to f} M_{f \to e} = I = M_{f \to e} M_{e \to f}Me→f​Mf→e​=I=Mf→e​Me→f​ so Mf→e=(Me→f)−1M_{f \to e} = (M_{e \to f})^{-1}Mf→e​=(Me→f​)−1
    • If T:V→VT : V \to VT:V→V is linear, then Te=Mf→eTfMe→fT_e = M_{f \to e} T_f M_{e \to f}Te​=Mf→e​Tf​Me→f​
  • N(A)N(A)N(A) is the eigenspace with eigenvalue 0
  • If Rn\R^nRn has a basis of eigenvectors of AAA, then AAA is diagonalisable
    • Let columns of PPP be eigenvectors (vi)(v_i)(vi​) of AAA (with corresponding eigenvalues (λi)(\lambda_i)(λi​)); then P=Me→vP = M_{e \to v}P=Me→v​ is change of basis matrix from standard basis e=(ei)e = (e_i)e=(ei​) to basis of eigenvectors v=(vi)v = (v_i)v=(vi​)
    • Then D=P−1APD = P^{-1}APD=P−1AP is diagonal; D=diag⁡(λ1,…,λn)D = \operatorname{diag}(\lambda_1,\dotsc,\lambda_n)D=diag(λ1​,…,λn​), so A=PDP−1A = PDP^{-1}A=PDP−1
      • For diagonal DDD, eigenvalues are diagonal entries λi\lambda_iλi​ with respective eigenvectors eie_iei​
    • det⁡A=∏λi\det A = \prod \lambda_idetA=∏λi​ is the product of eigenvalues (with multiplicity)
    • tr⁡A=∑λi\tr A = \sum \lambda_itrA=∑λi​ is the sum of eigenvalues (with multiplicity)
  • A basis for V={(x,y,z)∈R3:ax+by+cz=0}V = \{(x,y,z) \in \R^3 : ax + by + cz = 0\}V={(x,y,z)∈R3:ax+by+cz=0} (a,b,c≠0a,b,c \neq 0a,b,c=0) is {(a,−b,0),(0,b,−c)}\{(a,-b,0),(0,b,-c)\}{(a,−b,0),(0,b,−c)}
    • Note (a,b,c)(a,b,c)(a,b,c) is normal to VVV, so (a,−b,0)(a,-b,0)(a,−b,0) and (0,b,−c)(0,b,-c)(0,b,−c) are normal to (a,b,c)(a,b,c)(a,b,c) thus lie in VVV; these are clearly lin. indep
    • To recover Cartesian equation from tangent vectors, take cross product

2. Multivariable calculus

  • For a map F=(F1,...,Fm):U→RmF = (F_1,...,F_m) : U \to \R^mF=(F1​,...,Fm​):U→Rm (with U⊆RnU \subseteq \R^nU⊆Rn open), total derivative (or matrix derivative) of FFF is
    DF=(∂F1/∂x1∂F1/∂x2⋯∂F1/∂xn∂F2/∂x1∂F2/∂x2⋯∂F2/∂xn⋮⋮⋱⋮∂Fm/∂x1∂Fm/∂x2⋯∂Fm/∂xn)=(—∇F1——∇F2—⋮—∇Fm—)=(∣∣∣Fx1Fx2⋯Fxn∣∣∣)DF = \begin{pmatrix} \partial F_1/\partial x_1 & \partial F_1/\partial x_2 & \dotsb & \partial F_1/\partial x_n \\ \partial F_2/\partial x_1 & \partial F_2/\partial x_2 & \dotsb & \partial F_2/\partial x_n \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ \partial F_m/\partial x_1 & \partial F_m/\partial x_2 & \dotsb & \partial F_m/\partial x_n \\ \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \text{---} & \nabla F_1 & \text{---} \\ \text{---} & \nabla F_2 & \text{---} \\ & \vdots & \\ \text{---} & \nabla F_m & \text{---} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \vert & \vert & & \vert \\ F_{x_1} & F_{x_2} & \dotsb & F_{x_n} \\ \vert & \vert & & \vert \end{pmatrix}DF=⎝⎛​∂F1​/∂x1​∂F2​/∂x1​⋮∂Fm​/∂x1​​∂F1​/∂x2​∂F2​/∂x2​⋮∂Fm​/∂x2​​⋯⋯⋱⋯​∂F1​/∂xn​∂F2​/∂xn​⋮∂Fm​/∂xn​​⎠⎞​=⎝⎛​———​∇F1​∇F2​⋮∇Fm​​———​⎠⎞​=⎝⎛​∣Fx1​​∣​∣Fx2​​∣​⋯​∣Fxn​​∣​⎠⎞​
    where ∇Fi\nabla F_i∇Fi​ is the gradient (as a row vector) and FxjF_{x_j}Fxj​​ is the partial derivative of FFF w.r.t. xjx_jxj​ (as a column vector)
    • The (i,j)(i,j)(i,j)-entry of DFDFDF is ∂Fi/∂xj\partial F_i/\partial x_j∂Fi​/∂xj​
    • When m=1m = 1m=1, we have f:U→Rf : U \to \Rf:U→R; the gradient of fff is ∇f=(fx1,fx2,…,fxn)\nabla f = (f_{x_1},f_{x_2},\dotsc,f_{x_n})∇f=(fx1​​,fx2​​,…,fxn​​)
  • Directional derivative of F:U→RmF : U \to \R^mF:U→Rm (for U⊆RnU \subseteq \R^nU⊆Rn open) at x∈Ux \in Ux∈U in direction v∈TxU≅Rnv \in T_xU \cong \R^nv∈Tx​U≅Rn is DxF(v)=DF(x) vD_x F(v) = DF(x) \, vDx​F(v)=DF(x)v
    • Here DxF:TxU→TF(x)Rm≅RmD_x F : T_xU \to T_{F(x)}\R^m \cong \R^mDx​F:Tx​U→TF(x)​Rm≅Rm is the derivative of FFF at xxx
    • When m=1m = 1m=1, we have f:U→Rf : U \to \Rf:U→R; the directional derivative of fff at x∈Ux \in Ux∈U in direction v∈TxU≅Rnv \in T_xU \cong \R^nv∈Tx​U≅Rn is Dxf(v)=∇f(x)⋅vD_x f(v) = \nabla f(x) \cdot vDx​f(v)=∇f(x)⋅v
  • Properties of matrix derivatives:
    • (i) Let F:Rn→RnF : \R^n \to \R^nF:Rn→Rn be the identity map; then matrix derivative is DF=IDF = IDF=I
    • (ii) (Chain rule) Let F:Rn→RmF : \R^n \to \R^mF:Rn→Rm, G:Rm→RℓG : \R^m \to \R^\ellG:Rm→Rℓ; then matrix derivative of G∘F:Rn→RℓG \circ F : \R^n \to \R^\ellG∘F:Rn→Rℓ is
      D(G∘F)=(DG)(DF)D(G \circ F) = (DG)(DF)D(G∘F)=(DG)(DF)
    • (iii) (Inverse function theorem) If F:Rn→RnF : \R^n \to \R^nF:Rn→Rn has inverse F−1:Rn→RnF^{-1} : \R^n \to \R^nF−1:Rn→Rn, then DF−1=(DF)−1DF^{-1} = (DF)^{-1}DF−1=(DF)−1
  • Definition 2.25. A function f:U→Rf : U \to \Rf:U→R (U⊆RU \subseteq \RU⊆R) is CkC^kCk-smooth if, for all n∈Zn \in \Zn∈Z s.t. 1≤n≤k1 \leq n \leq k1≤n≤k, f(n)f^{(n)}f(n) exists and is continuous
    • Definition 2.26. f:U→Rf : U \to \Rf:U→R is C∞C^\inftyC∞-smooth (or just smooth) if for all integers n>0n > 0n>0, f(n)f^{(n)}f(n) exists
  • Definition 2.27. A function F:U→RmF : U \to \R^mF:U→Rm (U⊆RnU \subseteq \R^nU⊆Rn) is CkC^kCk-smooth if all partial derivatives of all components of FFF of all orders up to kkk exist and are continuous
    • Definition 2.28. F:U→RmF : U \to \R^mF:U→Rm is C∞C^\inftyC∞-smooth (or just smooth) if all partial derivatives of all components of FFF of all orders exist
  • Proposition 2.30. For any A∈Mm×n(R)A \in M_{m \times n}(\R)A∈Mm×n​(R), DTA=ADT_A = ADTA​=A

2. Curves and their parametrisations

1. Introducing curves

1.3. Parametrised curves

  • Definition 1.2. A (parametrised) curve in Rn\R^nRn is a continuous map γ:I→Rn\gamma : I \to \R^nγ:I→Rn for I⊆RI \sube \RI⊆R an interval
  • Definition 1.3. The image of a curve γ:I→Rn\gamma : I \to \R^nγ:I→Rn is γ(I)\gamma(I)γ(I)
    • Often referred to as a "curve"
  • Definition 1.5. For γ:I→Rn\gamma : I \to \R^nγ:I→Rn a parametrised curve, its coordinate functions γ1,…,γn:I→R\gamma_1,\dotsc,\gamma_n : I \to \Rγ1​,…,γn​:I→R are s.t. γ=(γ1,…,γn)\gamma = (\gamma_1,\dotsc,\gamma_n)γ=(γ1​,…,γn​) is given by
    t↦(γ1(t),…,γn(t))t \mapsto (\gamma_1(t),\dotsc,\gamma_n(t))t↦(γ1​(t),…,γn​(t))
    • For n=2n = 2n=2, write γ1=x\gamma_1 = xγ1​=x, γ2=y\gamma_2 = yγ2​=y
    • For n=3n = 3n=3, write γ1=x\gamma_1 = xγ1​=x, γ2=y\gamma_2 = yγ2​=y, γ3=z\gamma_3 = zγ3​=z
  • Definition 1.9. Let γ:I→Rn\gamma : I \to \R^nγ:I→Rn be a curve
    • For integers k≥1k \geq 1k≥1, γ\gammaγ is CkC^kCk-smooth if γ\gammaγ is a CkC^kCk-smooth function
    • γ\gammaγ is (C∞C^\inftyC∞-)smooth if γ\gammaγ is a C∞C^\inftyC∞-smooth function
    • γ\gammaγ is CkC^kCk-smooth iff each γi\gamma_iγi​ is CkC^kCk-smooth (as functions)
    • By default, we assume γ\gammaγ is C∞C^\inftyC∞-smooth
  • Definition 1.22. For C⊆RnC \subseteq \R^nC⊆Rn, if there is a curve γ:I→Rn\gamma : I \to \R^nγ:I→Rn s.t. γ(I)=C\gamma(I) = Cγ(I)=C, then γ\gammaγ parametrises CCC

1.6. Derivative of a parametrised curve

  • The derivative of a (smooth) curve γ:I→Rn\gamma : I \to \R^nγ:I→Rn is
    γ˙:I→Rn,t↦(γ1′(t),…,γn′(t))\dot{\gamma} : I \to \R^n, \quad t \mapsto (\gamma_1'(t),\dotsc,\gamma_n'(t))γ˙​:I→Rn,t↦(γ1′​(t),…,γn′​(t))
    • Definition 1.25. At γ(t0)\gamma(t_0)γ(t0​) on a curve γ:I→Rn\gamma : I \to \R^nγ:I→Rn (where t0∈It_0 \in It0​∈I), the derivative γ˙(t0)\dot{\gamma}(t_0)γ˙​(t0​) is the tangent vector or velocity vector to γ\gammaγ at γ(t0)\gamma(t_0)γ(t0​)
  • Definition 1.27. For a differentiable curve γ:I→Rn\gamma : I \to \R^nγ:I→Rn,
    • (i) The velocity of γ\gammaγ is γ˙\dot{\gamma}γ˙​
    • (ii) The speed of γ\gammaγ is ∥γ˙∥\norm{\dot{\gamma}}∥γ˙​∥
    • (iii) γ\gammaγ has unit speed if ∥γ˙∥=1\norm{\dot{\gamma}} = 1∥γ˙​∥=1
    • (iv) γ\gammaγ has constant speed if ∥γ˙∥=c\norm{\dot{\gamma}} = c∥γ˙​∥=c
    • Definition 1.29. If γ\gammaγ is twice differentiable, its acceleration is γ¨\ddot{\gamma}γ¨​
    • Note: for c∈Rc \in \Rc∈R, we identify it with the constant map x↦cx \mapsto cx↦c

1.7. Arclength

  • Definition 1.30. The arclength of a smooth curve γ\gammaγ over I=[a,b]I = [a,b]I=[a,b] is
    L(γ)=∫ab∥γ˙(t)∥ dtL(\gamma) = \int_a^b \norm{\dot{\gamma}(t)}\,dtL(γ)=∫ab​∥γ˙​(t)∥dt
    • The arclength function of γ:I→Rn\gamma : I \to \R^nγ:I→Rn, given starting time t0∈It_0 \in It0​∈I, is s:I→Rs : I \to \Rs:I→R,
      t↦∫t0t∥γ˙(τ)∥ dτt \mapsto \int_{t_0}^t \norm{\dot{\gamma}(\tau)}\,d\taut↦∫t0​t​∥γ˙​(τ)∥dτ
    • If γ\gammaγ has unit speed, the length of γ\gammaγ is L(γ)=∫IdsL(\gamma) = \int_I dsL(γ)=∫I​ds

1.8. Unit speed curves

  • Definition 1.33. A unit speed parametrisation of a curve is also called an arclength parametrisation
  • Proposition 1.34. If γ\gammaγ is unit speed, then γ˙⋅γ¨=0\dot{\gamma} \cdot \ddot{\gamma} = 0γ˙​⋅γ¨​=0
    • Dot product rule: (v⋅w)′=v′⋅w+v⋅w′(v \cdot w)' = v' \cdot w + v \cdot w'(v⋅w)′=v′⋅w+v⋅w′
  • Proposition 1.35. If γ˙\dot{\gamma}γ˙​ is constant, then γ\gammaγ is a line or a point

2. Reparametrisation and regularity

2.1. Reparametrisation

  • Definition 2.5. A function ϕ:I→J\phi : I \to Jϕ:I→J is a diffeomorphism if it is bijective, smooth, and has a smooth inverse
    • If we replace "smooth" with "continuous", we get a homeomorphism
  • Definition 2.6. Let γ:I→Rn\gamma : I \to \R^nγ:I→Rn and δ:J→Rn\delta : J \to \R^nδ:J→Rn be smooth curves; then δ\deltaδ is a reparametrisation of γ\gammaγ if there is a diffeomorphism ϕ:J→I\phi : J \to Iϕ:J→I s.t. δ=γ∘ϕ\delta = \gamma \circ \phiδ=γ∘ϕ
    • Exercise 27. Reparametrisation is an equivalence relation on the set of parametrised curves

2.2. Unit speed reparametrisations

  • Definition 2.12. A point γ(t0)\gamma(t_0)γ(t0​) of a smooth curve γ:I→Rn\gamma : I \to \R^nγ:I→Rn is
    • regular if γ˙(t0)≠0\dot{\gamma}(t_0) \neq 0γ˙​(t0​)=0
    • singular if γ˙(t0)=0\dot{\gamma}(t_0) = 0γ˙​(t0​)=0
    • A curve is regular if all its points are regular
  • Proposition 2.14. A smooth curve has a unit speed reparametrisation iff it is regular
    • Lemma 2.15. For γ:I→Rn\gamma : I \to \R^nγ:I→Rn a smooth curve and δ:J→Rn\delta : J \to \R^nδ:J→Rn a reparametrisation of γ\gammaγ via the diffeomorphism ϕ:J→I\phi : J \to Iϕ:J→I (i.e. δ=γ∘ϕ\delta = \gamma \circ \phiδ=γ∘ϕ), we have δ˙=(γ˙∘ϕ) ϕ′\dot{\delta} = (\dot{\gamma} \circ \phi)\, \phi'δ˙=(γ˙​∘ϕ)ϕ′
  • Algorithm (Unit speed reparametrisation). For regular γ:I→R\gamma : I \to \Rγ:I→R:
    • Find an arclength function s:I→R≥0s : I \to \R_{\geq 0}s:I→R≥0​
    • Restrict sss to bijection ψ:I→J\psi : I \to Jψ:I→J, t↦s(t)t \mapsto s(t)t↦s(t)
      • Works since γ\gammaγ is regular, so ∥γ˙∥>0\norm{\dot{\gamma}} > 0∥γ˙​∥>0
      • J:=s(I)J := s(I)J:=s(I) is interval by IVT and continuity (as it is smooth, with s′=∥γ˙∥s' = \norm{\dot{\gamma}}s′=∥γ˙​∥)
    • Invert function to obtain diffeomorphism ϕ:=ψ−1:J→I\phi := \psi^{-1} : J \to Iϕ:=ψ−1:J→I
    • Unit speed reparametrisation of γ\gammaγ is δ=γ∘ϕ:J→Rn\delta = \gamma \circ \phi : J \to \R^nδ=γ∘ϕ:J→Rn

3. Closed curves

3.2. Periodic curves and their periods

  • Definition 3.1. Let γ:R→Rn\gamma : \R \to \R^nγ:R→Rn be a curve
    • For T>0T > 0T>0, γ\gammaγ is TTT-periodic if for all t∈Rt \in \Rt∈R, γ(t+T)=γ(t)\gamma(t + T) = \gamma(t)γ(t+T)=γ(t)
    • If γ\gammaγ is TTT-periodic for some T≠0T \neq 0T=0, we say it is periodic
  • Definition 3.3. The period of a periodic curve γ\gammaγ is the smallest T>0T > 0T>0 s.t. it is TTT-periodic
  • Proposition 3.5. If a curve γ:R→Rn\gamma : \R \to \R^nγ:R→Rn is non-constant and periodic, it has a period
  • Definition 3.6. If γ:R→Rn\gamma : \R \to \R^nγ:R→Rn is a periodic curve of period TTT, its length is
    L(γ)=∫0T∥γ˙(t)∥ dtL(\gamma) = \int_0^T \norm{\dot{\gamma}(t)}\,dtL(γ)=∫0T​∥γ˙​(t)∥dt
    • If γ\gammaγ is unit speed, then L(γ)=TL(\gamma) = TL(γ)=T

3.3. Self-intersections

  • Definition 3.7. Let γ:R→Rn\gamma : \R \to \R^nγ:R→Rn be periodic with period TTT; we say γ\gammaγ has a self-intersection at ppp if there exist distinct a,b∈Ra,b \in \Ra,b∈R s.t.
    • (i) γ(a)=γ(b)=p\gamma(a) = \gamma(b) = pγ(a)=γ(b)=p, and
    • (ii) T∤a−bT \nmid a - bT∤a−b (i.e. a−b∉TZa - b \not\in T\Za−b∈TZ)
  • Definition 3.8. A curve without self-intersections is called simple

4. Curves as subsets and equations (optional)

  • Definition 4.1. The open ball of radius RRR centred at a∈Rna \in \R^na∈Rn, denoted BR(a)B_R(a)BR​(a), is the set of all points x∈Rnx \in \R^nx∈Rn s.t. ∥x−a∥<R\norm{x - a} < R∥x−a∥<R
  • Definition 4.2. A map f:X→Yf : X \to Yf:X→Y is a homeomorphism if it is continuous, bijective, with continuous inverse
    • Two sets (topological spaces) are homeomorphic if there is a homeomorphism f:X→Yf : X \to Yf:X→Y
  • Definition 4.3. A set C⊆RnC \subseteq \R^nC⊆Rn is an embedded curve if for every p∈Cp \in Cp∈C there is an open ball BBB containing ppp s.t. C∩BC \cap BC∩B is homeo. to an open interval
    • I.e. there is an open interval I⊆RI \subseteq \RI⊆R and a homeomorphism γ:I→C∩B\gamma : I \to C \cap Bγ:I→C∩B
    • Useful fact: homeomorphisms (and continuous maps) preserve connectedness
  • Definition 4.8. A set C⊆RnC \subseteq \R^nC⊆Rn is an embedded regular curve if for every p∈Cp \in Cp∈C there is an open ball BBB containing ppp, an open interval I⊆RI \subseteq \RI⊆R, and a homeomorphism γ:I→C∩B\gamma : I \to C \cap Bγ:I→C∩B s.t. γ\gammaγ is a regular (parametrised) curve
  • Lemma 4.10. If f:U→Rf : U \to \Rf:U→R (with U⊆RU \subseteq \RU⊆R open) is a smooth function,
    • (i) {(x,f(x)):x∈U}⊆R2\{(x,f(x)) : x \in U\} \subseteq \R^2{(x,f(x)):x∈U}⊆R2 is a regular embedded curve
    • (ii) {(f(y),y):y∈U}⊆R2\{(f(y),y) : y \in U\} \subseteq \R^2{(f(y),y):y∈U}⊆R2 is a regular embedded curve
  • Definition 4.11. For f:U→Rf : U \to \Rf:U→R, a level set of fff is a subset f−1(c):={x∈U:f(x)=c}f^{-1}(c) := \{x \in U : f(x) = c\}f−1(c):={x∈U:f(x)=c} for some c∈Rc \in \Rc∈R
  • Definition 4.12. For a function f:X→Yf : X \to Yf:X→Y with y∈Yy \in Yy∈Y and S⊆YS \subseteq YS⊆Y, define the preimage of y,Sy,Sy,S under fff as
    f−1(y)={x∈X:f(x)=y}andf−1(S)={x∈X:f(x)∈S}f^{-1}(y) = \{x \in X : f(x) = y\} \quad \text{and} \quad f^{-1}(S) = \{x \in X : f(x) \in S\}f−1(y)={x∈X:f(x)=y}andf−1(S)={x∈X:f(x)∈S}
  • Theorem 4.18. For a smooth function f:R2→Rf : \R^2 \to \Rf:R2→R and a point p∈f−1(c)p \in f^{-1}(c)p∈f−1(c) with ∇f(p)≠0\nabla f(p) \neq 0∇f(p)=0, then there is an open ball containing ppp s.t. f−1(c)∩Bf^{-1}(c) \cap Bf−1(c)∩B is a regular embedded curve
  • Theorem 4.20. Let γ:I→R2\gamma : I \to \R^2γ:I→R2 be a regular curve and consider p=γ(t0)p = \gamma(t_0)p=γ(t0​); then there is ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0, an open nbhd UUU of ppp and a smooth map f:U→Rf : U \to \Rf:U→R s.t. γ((t0−ϵ,t0+ϵ))⊆f−1(0)\gamma((t_0 - \epsilon,t_0 + \epsilon)) \subseteq f^{-1}(0)γ((t0​−ϵ,t0​+ϵ))⊆f−1(0)

3. How curves curve

1. The curvature of a curve

1.3. Curvature of a regular curve

  • Definition 1.1. For γ:I→Rn\gamma : I \to \R^nγ:I→Rn a unit speed curve, the curvature of γ\gammaγ is the map κ:=∥γ¨∥:I→[0,∞)\kappa := \norm{\ddot{\gamma}} : I \to [0,\infty)κ:=∥γ¨​∥:I→[0,∞), t↦∥γ¨(t)∥t \mapsto \norm{\ddot{\gamma}(t)}t↦∥γ¨​(t)∥
    • Note: κ≥0\kappa \geq 0κ≥0; if κ(s)≠0\kappa(s) \neq 0κ(s)=0 everywhere, then κ>0\kappa > 0κ>0
  • Definition 1.4. For a regular curve γ:I→Rn\gamma : I \to \R^nγ:I→Rn, the curvature of γ\gammaγ is the curvature of a unit speed reparametrisation δ=γ∘ϕ\delta = \gamma \circ \phiδ=γ∘ϕ
    • I.e. κγ:=κδ∘ϕ−1\kappa_\gamma := \kappa_\delta \circ \phi^{-1}κγ​:=κδ​∘ϕ−1
  • Definition 2.9. For intervals I,J⊆RI,J \subseteq \RI,J⊆R, a diffeomorphism ϕ:I→J\phi : I \to Jϕ:I→J is
    • orientation preserving if ϕ\phiϕ is increasing, and
    • orientation reversing if ϕ\phiϕ is decreasing
  • Definition 2.11. Let γ,δ\gamma,\deltaγ,δ be curves s.t. δ\deltaδ is a reparametrisation of γ\gammaγ, i.e. δ=γ∘ϕ\delta = \gamma \circ \phiδ=γ∘ϕ for some diffeomorphism (of intervals) ϕ\phiϕ
    • If ϕ\phiϕ is orientation preserving, we say δ\deltaδ is an orientation-preserving reparametrisation of γ\gammaγ
    • If ϕ\phiϕ is orientation reversing, we say δ\deltaδ is an orientation-reversing reparametrisation of γ\gammaγ
  • Proposition 1.7. If β:I→Rn\beta : I \to \R^nβ:I→Rn and δ:J→Rn\delta : J \to \R^nδ:J→Rn are unit speed reparametrisations of γ\gammaγ with curvatures κβ\kappa_\betaκβ​ and κδ\kappa_\deltaκδ​,
    • (i) If β\betaβ is an orientation-preserving reparam. of δ\deltaδ, then there is c∈Rc \in \Rc∈R s.t. β=δ∘ϕ\beta = \delta \circ \phiβ=δ∘ϕ via ϕ:I→J\phi : I \to Jϕ:I→J, s↦s+cs \mapsto s + cs↦s+c
    • (ii) If β\betaβ is an orientation-reversing reparam. of δ\deltaδ, then there is c∈Rc \in \Rc∈R s.t. β=δ∘ϕ\beta = \delta \circ \phiβ=δ∘ϕ via ϕ:I→J\phi : I \to Jϕ:I→J, s↦−s+cs \mapsto -s + cs↦−s+c
    • Moreover, in any case, κβ=κδ∘ϕ\kappa_\beta = \kappa_\delta \circ \phiκβ​=κδ​∘ϕ (so curvature is well-defined up to translation/reversal)

1.5. A formula for curvature

  • Proposition. Let γ:I→Rn\gamma : I \to \R^nγ:I→Rn be regular; then its curvature is given by
    κ=∥γ¨(γ˙⋅γ˙)−γ˙(γ˙⋅γ¨)∥∥γ˙∥4\kappa = \frac{\norm{\ddot{\gamma}(\dot{\gamma} \cdot \dot{\gamma}) - \dot{\gamma}(\dot{\gamma} \cdot \ddot{\gamma})}}{\norm{\dot{\gamma}}^4}κ=∥γ˙​∥4∥γ¨​(γ˙​⋅γ˙​)−γ˙​(γ˙​⋅γ¨​)∥​
    • Lemma 1.13. If δ\deltaδ is a unit speed reparam. of γ\gammaγ with δ=γ∘ϕ\delta = \gamma \circ \phiδ=γ∘ϕ, then
      δ˙=(γ˙∥γ˙∥)∘ϕ\dot{\delta} = \left(\frac{\dot{\gamma}}{\norm{\dot{\gamma}}}\right) \circ \phiδ˙=(∥γ˙​∥γ˙​​)∘ϕ
    • Can also show
      ϕ′=(1∥γ˙∥)∘ϕ,∥γ˙∥′=γ˙⋅γ¨∥γ˙∥,andδ¨=(γ¨(γ˙⋅γ˙)−γ˙(γ˙⋅γ¨)∥γ˙∥4)∘ϕ\phi' = \left(\frac{1}{\norm{\dot{\gamma}}}\right) \circ \phi, \quad \norm{\dot{\gamma}}' = \frac{\dot{\gamma} \cdot \ddot{\gamma}}{\norm{\dot{\gamma}}}, \quad \text{and} \quad \ddot{\delta} = \left(\frac{\ddot{\gamma}(\dot{\gamma} \cdot \dot{\gamma}) - \dot{\gamma}(\dot{\gamma} \cdot \ddot{\gamma})}{\norm{\dot{\gamma}}^4}\right) \circ \phiϕ′=(∥γ˙​∥1​)∘ϕ,∥γ˙​∥′=∥γ˙​∥γ˙​⋅γ¨​​,andδ¨=(∥γ˙​∥4γ¨​(γ˙​⋅γ˙​)−γ˙​(γ˙​⋅γ¨​)​)∘ϕ
  • Theorem 1.9. Let γ:I→R3\gamma : I \to \R^3γ:I→R3 be regular; then its curvature is given by
    κ=∥γ¨×γ˙∥∥γ˙∥3\kappa = \frac{\norm{\ddot{\gamma} \times \dot{\gamma}}}{\norm{\dot{\gamma}}^3}κ=∥γ˙​∥3∥γ¨​×γ˙​∥​
    • Lemma 1.12. For u,v,w∈R3u,v,w \in \R^3u,v,w∈R3,
      u×(v×w)=(u⋅w)v−(u⋅v)wu \times (v \times w) = (u \cdot w)v - (u \cdot v)wu×(v×w)=(u⋅w)v−(u⋅v)w
    • Lemma 1.14. If δ\deltaδ is a unit speed reparam. of γ\gammaγ with δ=γ∘ϕ\delta = \gamma \circ \phiδ=γ∘ϕ, then
      δ¨=(γ˙×(γ¨×γ˙)∥γ˙∥4)∘ϕ\ddot{\delta} = \left(\frac{\dot{\gamma} \times (\ddot{\gamma} \times \dot{\gamma})}{\norm{\dot{\gamma}}^4}\right) \circ \phiδ¨=(∥γ˙​∥4γ˙​×(γ¨​×γ˙​)​)∘ϕ
    • For regular curve γ:I→R2\gamma : I \to \R^2γ:I→R2 and embedding ι:R2→R3\iota : \R^2 \to \R^3ι:R2→R3, (x,y)↦(x,y,0)(x,y) \mapsto (x,y,0)(x,y)↦(x,y,0),
      • α:=ι∘γ:I→R3\alpha := \iota \circ \gamma : I \to \R^3α:=ι∘γ:I→R3 is a regular curve
      • We have
        κγ=κα=∥α¨×α˙∥∥α˙∥3\kappa_{\gamma} = \kappa_{\alpha} = \frac{\norm{\ddot{\alpha} \times \dot{\alpha}}}{\norm{\dot{\alpha}}^3}κγ​=κα​=∥α˙∥3∥α¨×α˙∥​
  • Definition. An isometry of a metric space (X,d)(X,d)(X,d) is a map f:X→Xf : X \to Xf:X→X, s.t. d(x,y)=d(f(x),f(y))d(x,y) = d(f(x),f(y))d(x,y)=d(f(x),f(y)) for all x,y∈Xx,y \in Xx,y∈X
    • The set of bijective isometries of a space forms a group under composition
    • Examples in R3\R^3R3 include translations, rotations, reflections, and finite compositions of these
    • E.g. A helix HHH has constant curvature; there are many isometries f:R3→R3f : \R^3 \to \R^3f:R3→R3 with f(H)=Hf(H) = Hf(H)=H, namely screw motions

2. Signed curvature (in R2\R^2R2)

2.1. Turning angle

  • Definition 2.1. A turning angle for a regular curve γ:I→R2\gamma : I \to \R^2γ:I→R2 is a continuous map φ:I→R\varphi : I \to \Rφ:I→R s.t., for all t∈It \in It∈I,
γ˙(t)=∥γ˙(t)∥(cos⁡φ(t),sin⁡φ(t))\dot{\gamma}(t) = \lVert\dot{\gamma}(t)\rVert (\cos\varphi(t),\sin\varphi(t))γ˙​(t)=∥γ˙​(t)∥(cosφ(t),sinφ(t))
  • Turning angle is defined up to multiples of 2π2\pi2π
  • Proposition 2.2. For γ:I→R2\gamma : I \to \R^2γ:I→R2 regular, with s0∈Is_0 \in Is0​∈I and r0∈Rr_0 \in \Rr0​∈R s.t.
    γ˙(s0)=∥γ˙(s0)∥(cos⁡φ0,sin⁡φ0),\dot{\gamma}(s_0) = \lVert\dot{\gamma}(s_0)\rVert (\cos\varphi_0,\sin\varphi_0),γ˙​(s0​)=∥γ˙​(s0​)∥(cosφ0​,sinφ0​),
    there is a unique turning angle φ:I→R\varphi : I \to \Rφ:I→R for γ\gammaγ s.t. φ(s0)=φ0\varphi(s_0) = \varphi_0φ(s0​)=φ0​

2.2. Signed curvature

  • Definition 2.3. For a unit speed curve γ:I→R2\gamma : I \to \R^2γ:I→R2 with turning angle φ\varphiφ, the signed curvature of γ\gammaγ is κs:=φ˙:I→R\kappa_s := \dot\varphi : I \to \Rκs​:=φ˙​:I→R
  • Definition 2.12. For a regular curve γ:I→R2\gamma : I \to \R^2γ:I→R2, the signed curvature of γ\gammaγ is the signed curvature of an orientation-preserving unit speed reparametrisation δ=γ∘ϕ\delta = \gamma \circ \phiδ=γ∘ϕ
    • I.e. κsγ=κsδ∘ϕ−1\kappa_s^\gamma = \kappa_s^\delta \circ \phi^{-1}κsγ​=κsδ​∘ϕ−1
  • Proposition 2.13. If β:I→R2\beta : I \to \R^2β:I→R2 and δ:J→R2\delta : J \to \R^2δ:J→R2 are orientation-preserving unit speed reparametrisations of γ\gammaγ (related by β=δ∘ϕ\beta = \delta \circ \phiβ=δ∘ϕ via ϕ:I→J\phi : I \to Jϕ:I→J, s↦s+cs \mapsto s + cs↦s+c for some c∈Rc \in \Rc∈R) with signed curvatures κsβ\kappa_s^\betaκsβ​ and κsδ\kappa_s^\deltaκsδ​, then κsβ=κsδ∘ϕ\kappa_s^\beta = \kappa_s^\delta \circ \phiκsβ​=κsδ​∘ϕ (so signed curvature is well-defined up to translation)
  • Proposition 2.23. If the unit speed curve γ:I→R2\gamma : I \to \R^2γ:I→R2 is given by γ=(x,y)\gamma = (x,y)γ=(x,y), then κs=x˙y¨−x¨y˙\kappa_s = \dot x \ddot y - \ddot x \dot yκs​=x˙y¨​−x¨y˙​
    • Uses T=γ˙=(cos⁡φ,sin⁡φ)T = \dot\gamma = (\cos\varphi,\sin\varphi)T=γ˙​=(cosφ,sinφ) to conclude x˙=cos⁡φ\dot x = \cos\varphix˙=cosφ and y˙=sin⁡φ\dot y = \sin\varphiy˙​=sinφ
  • Proposition 2.28. If the regular curve γ:I→R2\gamma : I \to \R^2γ:I→R2 is given by γ=(x,y)\gamma = (x,y)γ=(x,y), then
    κs=x˙y¨−x¨y˙∥γ˙∥3\kappa_s = \frac{\dot x \ddot y - \ddot x \dot y}{\norm{\dot\gamma}^3}κs​=∥γ˙​∥3x˙y¨​−x¨y˙​​

2.5. Planar principal normal

  • Definition 2.14. The planar principal normal NNN to a unit speed curve γ:I→R2\gamma : I \to \R^2γ:I→R2 is obtained by rotating the tangent T:=γ˙T := \dot{\gamma}T:=γ˙​ by π/2\pi/2π/2 anticlockwise
  • Lemma 2.15. If φ\varphiφ is a turning angle for a unit speed curve γ:I→R2\gamma : I \to \R^2γ:I→R2, then for s∈Is \in Is∈I,
    N(s)=(−sin⁡φ(s),cos⁡φ(s))N(s) = (-\sin\varphi(s),\cos\varphi(s))N(s)=(−sinφ(s),cosφ(s))
  • Lemma 2.16. If the unit speed curve γ:I→R2\gamma : I \to \R^2γ:I→R2 is given by γ=(x,y)\gamma = (x,y)γ=(x,y), then N=(−y˙,x˙)N = (-\dot y,\dot x)N=(−y˙​,x˙)
  • Proposition 2.18. If γ:I→R2\gamma : I \to \R^2γ:I→R2 is unit speed, then γ¨=T˙=κsN\ddot{\gamma} = \dot{T} = \kappa_s Nγ¨​=T˙=κs​N where κs\kappa_sκs​ is signed curvature and NNN is the principal normal

3. Integrating curvature

  • Definition 3.1.
    • (i) Total curvature of a unit speed curve γ:(a,b)→Rn\gamma : (a,b) \to \R^nγ:(a,b)→Rn is
      K=∫abκ(s) dsK = \int_a^b \kappa(s)\, dsK=∫ab​κ(s)ds
    • (ii) Total signed curvature of a unit speed curve γ:(a,b)→R2\gamma : (a,b) \to \R^2γ:(a,b)→R2 is
      Ks=∫abκs(s) dsK_s = \int_a^b \kappa_s(s)\, dsKs​=∫ab​κs​(s)ds
  • Definition 3.2.
    • (i) Total curvature of a closed unit speed curve γ:R→Rn\gamma : \R \to \R^nγ:R→Rn of period LLL is
      K=∫0Lκ(s) dsK = \int_0^L \kappa(s)\, dsK=∫0L​κ(s)ds
    • (ii) Total signed curvature of a closed unit speed curve γ:R→R2\gamma : \R \to \R^2γ:R→R2 of period LLL is
      Ks=∫0Lκs(s) dsK_s = \int_0^L \kappa_s(s)\, dsKs​=∫0L​κs​(s)ds
  • Proposition 3.6. Total signed curvature of a regular closed curve is an integer multiple of 2π2\pi2π
  • Definition 3.7. Given unit speed curve γ:I→R2\gamma : I \to \R^2γ:I→R2, let
    K+=∫κs>0κ(s) ds,K−=∫κs<0κ(s) dsK_+ = \int_{\kappa_s > 0} \kappa(s)\, ds, \quad K_- = \int_{\kappa_s < 0} \kappa(s)\, dsK+​=∫κs​>0​κ(s)ds,K−​=∫κs​<0​κ(s)ds
    • Note: K+,K−>0K_+,K_- > 0K+​,K−​>0
  • Lemma 3.8. For unit speed curve γ\gammaγ in R2\R^2R2, Ks=K+−K−K_s = K_+ - K_-Ks​=K+​−K−​ and K=K++K−K = K_+ + K_-K=K+​+K−​
  • Theorem 3.11. Let κS:I→R\kappa_S : I \to \RκS​:I→R be smooth; let s0∈Is_0 \in Is0​∈I, φ0∈R\varphi_0 \in \Rφ0​∈R, and p0∈R2p_0 \in \R^2p0​∈R2; then there is a unique unit speed curve γ:I→R2\gamma : I \to \R^2γ:I→R2 s.t.
    • (i) γ(s0)=p0\gamma(s_0) = p_0γ(s0​)=p0​,
    • (ii) γ˙(s0)=(cos⁡φ0,sin⁡φ0)\dot\gamma(s_0) = (\cos\varphi_0,\sin\varphi_0)γ˙​(s0​)=(cosφ0​,sinφ0​) (i.e. φ(s0)=φ0\varphi(s_0) = \varphi_0φ(s0​)=φ0​), and
    • (iii) the signed curvature of γ\gammaγ is κs\kappa_sκs​
    • Process:
      • (i) Integrate κs\kappa_sκs​ (using FTC) and use φ(s0)\varphi(s_0)φ(s0​) to obtain turning angle φ\varphiφ
      • (ii) Obtain velocity as γ˙=(cos⁡φ,sin⁡φ)\dot\gamma = (\cos\varphi,\sin\varphi)γ˙​=(cosφ,sinφ)
      • (iii) Integrate γ˙\dot\gammaγ˙​ and use γ(s0)\gamma(s_0)γ(s0​) to obtain γ\gammaγ
  • Theorem 3.13. Let α,β:I→R2\alpha,\beta : I \to \R^2α,β:I→R2 be unit speed with same signed curvature κs:I→R\kappa_s : I \to \Rκs​:I→R; then there is an isometry M:R2→R2M : \R^2 \to \R^2M:R2→R2 s.t. γ=M∘δ\gamma = M \circ \deltaγ=M∘δ

4. Curves in 3D space

4.1. Frenet frame for unit speed curves

  • Definition 4.1. If κ(s)≠0\kappa(s) \neq 0κ(s)=0, the principal normal NNN at γ(s)\gamma(s)γ(s) is
    N(s)=γ¨(s)κ(s)=γ¨(s)∥γ¨(s)∥N(s) = \frac{\ddot\gamma(s)}{\kappa(s)} = \frac{\ddot\gamma(s)}{\norm{\ddot\gamma(s)}}N(s)=κ(s)γ¨​(s)​=∥γ¨​(s)∥γ¨​(s)​
    • Remark 4.2. N=T˙/κN = \dot T/\kappaN=T˙/κ where T:=γ˙T := \dot\gammaT:=γ˙​
    • Remark 4.3. If γ\gammaγ not unit speed, then γ¨\ddot\gammaγ¨​ not usually orthogonal to TTT
    • Remark 4.6. When κ(s)=0\kappa(s) = 0κ(s)=0, N(s)N(s)N(s) is undefined (e.g. for straight line)
  • Definition 4.7. The binormal BBB is B=T×NB = T \times NB=T×N
  • Definition 4.8. The Frenet frame of γ\gammaγ at γ(s)\gamma(s)γ(s) (where κ(s)≠0\kappa(s) \neq 0κ(s)=0) is (T(s),N(s),B(s))(T(s),N(s),B(s))(T(s),N(s),B(s))
    • Forms right-handed orthonormal basis for R3\R^3R3
  • Lemma 4.10. If b1,…,bnb_1,\dotsc,b_nb1​,…,bn​ are orthonormal basis for Rn\R^nRn, then for v∈Rnv \in \R^nv∈Rn, v=a1b2+⋯+anbnv = a_1b_2 + \dotsb + a_nb_nv=a1​b2​+⋯+an​bn​ where ai=v⋅bia_i = v \cdot b_iai​=v⋅bi​
  • Definition 4.11. The torsion of unit speed γ:I→R3\gamma : I \to \R^3γ:I→R3 (with κ>0\kappa > 0κ>0) is τ:I→R\tau : I \to \Rτ:I→R defined by B˙=−τN\dot B = -\tau NB˙=−τN
  • Theorem 4.12 (Frenet-Serret equations). For unit speed γ:I→R3\gamma : I \to \R^3γ:I→R3 with κ>0\kappa > 0κ>0,
    T˙=κN,N˙=−κT+τB,B˙=−τN\dot T = \kappa N, \quad \dot N = -\kappa T + \tau B, \quad \dot B = -\tau NT˙=κN,N˙=−κT+τB,B˙=−τN
    Alternatively,
    dds(TNB)=(0κ0κ0τ0−τ0)(TNB)\frac{d}{ds} \begin{pmatrix} T \\ N \\ B \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & \kappa & 0 \\ \kappa & 0 & \tau \\ 0 & -\tau & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} T \\ N \\ B \end{pmatrix}dsd​⎝⎛​TNB​⎠⎞​=⎝⎛​0κ0​κ0−τ​0τ0​⎠⎞​⎝⎛​TNB​⎠⎞​
    where the coefficient matrix MMM is skew-symmetric, i.e. M⊤=−MM^\top = -MM⊤=−M
    • In 2D: embed R2\R^2R2 in R3\R^3R3 as R2×{0}\R^2 \times \{0\}R2×{0}; then τ=0\tau = 0τ=0 and T˙=κN\dot T = \kappa NT˙=κN, N˙=−κT\dot N = -\kappa TN˙=−κT
  • Proposition 4.16. For unit speed γ:I→R3\gamma : I \to \R^3γ:I→R3 with κ>0\kappa > 0κ>0, γ\gammaγ lies in a plane iff τ=0\tau = 0τ=0
  • Definition 4.17. Let γ\gammaγ be unit speed with Frenet frame (T,N,B)(T,N,B)(T,N,B)
    • The osculating plane of γ\gammaγ is the plane spanned by TTT and NNN
    • The normal plane of γ\gammaγ is the plane spanned by NNN and BBB
    • The rectifying plane of γ\gammaγ is the plane spanned by TTT and BBB
  • Theorem 4.20. Let κ>0\kappa > 0κ>0, τ\tauτ be smooth functions I→RI \to \RI→R; then given starting time s0∈Is_0 \in Is0​∈I and starting point p0∈R3p_0 \in \R^3p0​∈R3, and starting right-handed orthonormal frame (T0,N0,B0)(T_0,N_0,B_0)(T0​,N0​,B0​), there is a unique unit speed curve γ:I→R3\gamma : I \to \R^3γ:I→R3 s.t.
    • (i) γ(s0)=p0\gamma(s_0) = p_0γ(s0​)=p0​;
    • (ii) Frenet frame (T,N,B)(T,N,B)(T,N,B) of γ\gammaγ is s.t. (T(s0),N(s0),B(s0))=(T0,N0,B0)(T(s_0),N(s_0),B(s_0)) = (T_0,N_0,B_0)(T(s0​),N(s0​),B(s0​))=(T0​,N0​,B0​);
    • (iii) γ\gammaγ has curvature κ\kappaκ and torsion τ\tauτ
    • Idea: frame equations form system of 9 coupled ODEs; given T=γ˙T = \dot\gammaT=γ˙​, integrate to obtain γ\gammaγ

4.7. Frenet frame for regular curves

  • Lemma 4.21. For γ\gammaγ regular with κ>0\kappa > 0κ>0, and β\betaβ an orientation-preserving unit speed reparam. of γ\gammaγ with Frenet frame (T,N,B)(T,N,B)(T,N,B), we have, for γ(t)=β(s)\gamma(t) = \beta(s)γ(t)=β(s),
    B(s)=γ˙×γ¨∥γ˙×γ¨∥(t)B(s) = \frac{\dot\gamma \times \ddot\gamma}{\norm{\dot\gamma \times \ddot\gamma}}(t)B(s)=∥γ˙​×γ¨​∥γ˙​×γ¨​​(t)
    • T=γ˙/∥γ˙∥T = \dot\gamma/\norm{\dot\gamma}T=γ˙​/∥γ˙​∥ still works, and then N=B×TN = B \times TN=B×T
  • Proposition 4.22. If γ\gammaγ is regular in R3\R^3R3 with κ>0\kappa > 0κ>0, then
    τ=(γ˙×γ¨)⋅γ¨˙∥γ˙×γ¨∥2\tau = \frac{(\dot\gamma \times \ddot\gamma) \cdot \dot{\ddot\gamma}}{\norm{\dot\gamma \times \ddot\gamma}^2}τ=∥γ˙​×γ¨​∥2(γ˙​×γ¨​)⋅γ¨​˙​​

4. Simple closed curves

2. Jordan curve theorem

  • Definition 2.1. S⊆RnS \subseteq \R^nS⊆Rn is path-connected if for any p,q∈Sp,q \in Sp,q∈S there is a continuous curve γ:[0,1]→S\gamma : [0,1] \to Sγ:[0,1]→S s.t. γ(0)=p\gamma(0) = pγ(0)=p and γ(1)=q\gamma(1) = qγ(1)=q
  • Definition 2.2.
    • (i) S⊆RnS \subseteq \R^nS⊆Rn is bounded if there is R∈RR \in \RR∈R s.t. for any x∈Sx \in Sx∈S, ∥x∥<R\norm{x} < R∥x∥<R
    • (ii) S⊆RnS \subseteq \R^nS⊆Rn is unbounded if it is not bounded
  • Definition 2.3. S⊆RnS \subseteq \R^nS⊆Rn is open if for all x∈Sx \in Sx∈S there is r>0r > 0r>0 and open ball Br(x)B_r(x)Br​(x) s.t. Br(x)⊆SB_r(x) \subseteq SBr​(x)⊆S
  • Theorem 2.4 (Jordan curve theorem). For γ:R→R2\gamma : \R \to \R^2γ:R→R2 simple closed continuous curve, R2∖γ(R)\R^2 \setminus \gamma(\R)R2∖γ(R) is the disjoint union of two sets:
    • (i) the interior Int⁡(γ)\Int(\gamma)Int(γ), which is open, bounded, path connected; and
    • (ii) the exterior Ext⁡(γ)\Ext(\gamma)Ext(γ) which is open, unbounded, path-connected
  • Definition 2.10. A regular simple closed curve in R2\R^2R2 is oriented
    • (i) positively if NNN points into Int⁡(γ)\Int(\gamma)Int(γ)
    • (ii) negatively if NNN points into Ext⁡(γ)\Ext(\gamma)Ext(γ)
    • Recall: planar principal normal NNN is obtained by rotating TTT by π/2\pi/2π/2 anticlockwise

3. Properties of total curvature

  • Theorem 3.1 (Hopf's Umlaufsatz). For a regular simple closed curve γ\gammaγ in R2\R^2R2, Ks=±2πK_s = \pm 2\piKs​=±2π
    • Ks=2πK_s = 2\piKs​=2π when γ\gammaγ is positively oriented
    • Ks=−2πK_s = -2\piKs​=−2π when γ\gammaγ is negatively oriented
  • Definition 3.4. S⊆RnS \subseteq \R^nS⊆Rn is convex if for any p,q∈Sp,q \in Sp,q∈S the line segment from ppp to qqq lies entirely in SSS
  • Definition 3.5. A simple closed curve γ\gammaγ in R2\R^2R2 is convex if Int⁡(γ)\Int(\gamma)Int(γ) is a convex set
  • Theorem 3.6. For a simple closed curve γ\gammaγ in R2\R^2R2 with signed curvature κs\kappa_sκs​,
    • (i) κs≥0\kappa_s \geq 0κs​≥0 iff γ\gammaγ is positively oriented and convex
    • (ii) κs≤0\kappa_s \leq 0κs​≤0 iff γ\gammaγ is negatively oriented and convex
  • Definition 3.11. A curve γ:I→Rn\gamma : I \to \R^nγ:I→Rn is planar if its image lies on a 2-dimensional plane in Rn\R^nRn
  • Theorem 3.7 (Fenchel's theorem). For a regular closed curve γ\gammaγ in Rn\R^nRn of period LLL,
    K=∫0Lκ(s) ds≥2πK = \int_0^L \kappa(s)\, ds \geq 2\piK=∫0L​κ(s)ds≥2π
    with equality iff γ\gammaγ is simple, planar, convex
    • If γ\gammaγ not simple, or not planar, or not convex, then K>2πK > 2\piK>2π

4. Area enclosed by simple closed curve

  • Definition 4.1. The area enclosed by simple closed curve γ\gammaγ in R2\R^2R2 is
    A(γ)=∫Int⁡(γ)dx dy\mathcal{A}(\gamma) = \int_{\Int(\gamma)} dx\,dyA(γ)=∫Int(γ)​dxdy
  • Theorem 4.2 (Green's theorem). For f,g:R2→Rf,g : \R^2 \to \Rf,g:R2→R smooth and γ:R→Rn\gamma : \R \to \R^nγ:R→Rn smooth positively oriented simple closed curve,
    ∫Int⁡(γ)(∂g∂x−∂f∂y)dx dy=∮γf dx+g dy\int_{\Int(\gamma)} \left(\frac{\partial g}{\partial x} - \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}\right)dx\,dy = \oint_\gamma f\,dx + g\,dy∫Int(γ)​(∂x∂g​−∂y∂f​)dxdy=∮γ​fdx+gdy
  • Proposition 4.7. For γ:R→R2\gamma : \R \to \R^2γ:R→R2 smooth positively oriented simple closed curve with period TTT,
    A(γ)=∮γx dy=∮γ−y dx=12∮γx dy−y dx\mathcal{A}(\gamma) = \oint_\gamma x\,dy = \oint_\gamma -y\,dx = \frac{1}{2}\oint_\gamma x\,dy - y\,dxA(γ)=∮γ​xdy=∮γ​−ydx=21​∮γ​xdy−ydx
    • By chain rule: A(γ)=∫0Txy˙ dt=∫0T−yx˙ dt=12∫0T(xy˙−yx˙) dt\mathcal{A}(\gamma) = \int_0^T x\dot y\,dt = \int_0^T -y\dot x\,dt = \frac{1}{2}\int_0^T (x\dot y - y\dot x)\,dtA(γ)=∫0T​xy˙​dt=∫0T​−yx˙dt=21​∫0T​(xy˙​−yx˙)dt
  • Proposition 4.9. For γ:R→R2\gamma : \R \to \R^2γ:R→R2 smooth positively oriented simple closed curve of period TTT,
    A(γ)=12∮γr2 dθ=12∫0Tr2θ˙ dt\mathcal{A}(\gamma) = \frac{1}{2} \oint_\gamma r^2\,d\theta = \frac{1}{2} \int_0^T r^2 \dot\theta\, dtA(γ)=21​∮γ​r2dθ=21​∫0T​r2θ˙dt
    • Polar coordinates: x=rcos⁡θx = r\cos\thetax=rcosθ, y=rsin⁡θy = r\sin\thetay=rsinθ, i.e. γ=r(cos⁡θ,sin⁡θ)\gamma = r(\cos\theta,\sin\theta)γ=r(cosθ,sinθ)
  • Theorem 5.1 (Isoperimetric inequality). For a regular simple closed curve γ\gammaγ in R2\R^2R2 with length LLL, then
    A(γ)≤L24π\mathcal{A}(\gamma) \leq \frac{L^2}{4\pi}A(γ)≤4πL2​
    with equality iff γ\gammaγ is a circle
  • Theorem 5.2 (Wirtinger's inequality). Let F:[0,π]F : [0,\pi]F:[0,π] be smooth s.t. F(0)=F(π)=0F(0) = F(\pi) = 0F(0)=F(π)=0; then
    ∫0π(F˙2−F2) dt≥0\int_0^\pi (\dot F^2 - F^2)\, dt \geq 0∫0π​(F˙2−F2)dt≥0
    with equality iff F(t)=Dsin⁡tF(t) = D\sin tF(t)=Dsint for some D∈RD \in \RD∈R

6. Four vertex theorem

  • Definition 6.1. For a regular curve γ\gammaγ in R2\R^2R2, a vertex of γ\gammaγ is a point γ(t)\gamma(t)γ(t) where κ˙s(t)=0\dot\kappa_s(t) = 0κ˙s​(t)=0
    • If δ\deltaδ is a reparam. of γ\gammaγ, γ\gammaγ and δ\deltaδ have the same vertices
    • Vertices occur at critical points of signed curvature (position of steering wheel)
  • Theorem 6.5 (Four vertex theorem). Every regular simple closed curve in R2\R^2R2 has at least 4 vertices
    • Not true if not simple (see limaçon)

5. Surfaces and their parametrisations

2. Surfaces

  • Definition 2.1. S⊆RnS \subseteq \R^nS⊆Rn is an (embedded) surface if for every p∈Sp \in Sp∈S there is an open nbhd W⊆R3W \subseteq \R^3W⊆R3, an open set U⊆R2U \subseteq \R^2U⊆R2, and a homeomorphism σ:U→S∩W\sigma : U \to S \cap Wσ:U→S∩W
    • σ\sigmaσ is called a (coordinate) chart or surface patch of SSS
  • Definition 2.9. A relatively open subset of a surface SSS is a set Y=S∩WY = S \cap WY=S∩W where W⊆R3W \subseteq \R^3W⊆R3 is open
  • Definition 2.11. A collection of surface patches for SSS whose images cover SSS is an atlas for SSS
    • S⊆RnS \subseteq \R^nS⊆Rn is a surface if it has an atlas of coordinate charts (that cover SSS)
  • Lemma 2.16. The map f:R→S1f : \R \to S^1f:R→S1 defined by f(t)=(cos⁡t,sin⁡t)f(t) = (\cos t,\sin t)f(t)=(cost,sint) restricts to a homeomorphism g:(a,a+2π)→S1∖{f(a)}g : (a,a+2\pi) \to S^1 \setminus \{f(a)\}g:(a,a+2π)→S1∖{f(a)}
  • Proposition 2.18 (Graphs are surfaces). For a continuous map f:U→Rf : U \to \Rf:U→R for U⊆R2U \subseteq \R^2U⊆R2 open, its graph S={(x,y,f(x,y))∈R3:(x,y)∈U}S = \{(x,y,f(x,y)) \in \R^3 : (x,y) \in U\}S={(x,y,f(x,y))∈R3:(x,y)∈U} is a surface
  • Exercise 7. If f:A→Bf : A \to Bf:A→B is a homeomorphism and AAA is path-connected, then BBB is path-connected
    • Can use this to disprove something is a surface: cannot have homeomorphism σ:U→S∩W\sigma : U \to S \cap Wσ:U→S∩W if U∖σ−1(Y)U \setminus \sigma^{-1}(Y)U∖σ−1(Y) and (S∩W)∖Y(S \cap W) \setminus Y(S∩W)∖Y have different number of path(-connected) components
  • Definition 2.26. For charts σ:U→Y\sigma : U \to Yσ:U→Y and ρ:U′→Y′\rho : U' \to Y'ρ:U′→Y′ s.t. Y∩Y′≠∅Y \cap Y' \neq \varnothingY∩Y′=∅, let V=σ−1(Y∩Y′)V = \sigma^{-1}(Y \cap Y')V=σ−1(Y∩Y′) and V′=ρ−1(Y∩Y′)V' = \rho^{-1}(Y \cap Y')V′=ρ−1(Y∩Y′); then Φ:=ρ−1∘σ:V→V′\Phi := \rho^{-1} \circ \sigma : V \to V'Φ:=ρ−1∘σ:V→V′ is a transition map from σ\sigmaσ to ρ\rhoρ
    • Technically Φ=(ρ∣V′)−1∘σ∣V\Phi = (\rho|_{V'})^{-1} \circ \sigma|_VΦ=(ρ∣V′​)−1∘σ∣V​
    • Transition maps are homeomorphisms between open subsets of R2\R^2R2
    • For (u,v)∈V(u,v) \in V(u,v)∈V, σ(u,v)=ρ(Φ(u,v))\sigma(u,v) = \rho(\Phi(u,v))σ(u,v)=ρ(Φ(u,v))

3. Smooth surfaces

  • Proposition 3.4. For a surface patch σ\sigmaσ, the set of all directional derivatives of σ\sigmaσ at (u,v)(u,v)(u,v) is span⁡{σu(u,v),σv(u,v)}\span\{\sigma_u(u,v),\sigma_v(u,v)\}span{σu​(u,v),σv​(u,v)}
  • Definition 3.7. A smooth chart σ:U→Rn\sigma : U \to \R^nσ:U→Rn is regular at (u,v)∈U(u,v) \in U(u,v)∈U if σu(u,v),σv(u,v)\sigma_u(u,v),\sigma_v(u,v)σu​(u,v),σv​(u,v) are lin. indep.
    • σ\sigmaσ is regular if it is regular at all points of UUU (i.e. σu,σv\sigma_u,\sigma_vσu​,σv​ are lin. indep. on UUU)
  • Definition 3.8. A smooth surface is a surface with an atlas of regular charts
  • Lemma 3.11. For a m×nm \times nm×n matrix AAA with m≥nm \geq nm≥n, the following are equivalent:
    • (i) column vectors are lin. indep. in Rm\R^mRm
    • (ii) AAA has rank nnn
    • (iii) the linear map TA:Rn→RmT_A : \R^n \to \R^mTA​:Rn→Rm is injective
  • Proposition 3.12. For a surface patch σ:U→R3\sigma : U \to \R^3σ:U→R3, the following are equivlent:
    • (i) σ\sigmaσ is regular at (u,v)(u,v)(u,v)
    • (ii) Dσ(u,v)D\sigma(u,v)Dσ(u,v) has rank 2
    • (iii) the linear map of Dσ(u,v)D\sigma(u,v)Dσ(u,v) is injective
    • Note: f:U→Rnf : U \to \R^nf:U→Rn is an immersion if its derivative DpfD_p fDp​f is injective at every point in UUU

4. Verifying a smooth surface (tricks)

  • Propostion 4.3. v,w∈R3v,w \in \R^3v,w∈R3 are lin. indep. iff v×w≠0v \times w \neq 0v×w=0
  • Proposition 4.4 (Graphs are smooth surfaces). The graph of a smooth function f:U→Rf : U \to \Rf:U→R (for U⊆R2U \subseteq \R^2U⊆R2 open) is a smooth surface
  • Theorem 4.7 (Level sets are smooth surfaces). If for each p∈S⊆R3p \in S \subseteq \R^3p∈S⊆R3 there is an open nbhd WWW of ppp and a smooth f:W→Rf : W \to \Rf:W→R s.t. S∩W=f−1(c)S \cap W = f^{-1}(c)S∩W=f−1(c) for some c∈Rc \in \Rc∈R and ∇f(p)≠0\nabla f(p) \neq 0∇f(p)=0, then SSS is a smooth surface
    • Corollary 4.9. If there is smooth f:R3→Rf : \R^3 \to \Rf:R3→R and c∈Rc \in \Rc∈R s.t. S=f−1(c)S = f^{-1}(c)S=f−1(c) and ∇f(p)≠0\nabla f(p) \neq 0∇f(p)=0 for all p∈Sp \in Sp∈S, then SSS is a smooth surface
  • Theorem 4.13 (Continuous to homeomorphism). If f:A→Bf : A \to Bf:A→B is a continuous bijection where A⊆RnA \subseteq \R^nA⊆Rn is closed and bounded and B⊆RmB \subseteq \R^mB⊆Rm, then fff is a homeomorphism
    • Can extend chart σ:U→S∩W\sigma : U \to S \cap Wσ:U→S∩W to closure of UUU, show that's a homeomorphism (injective, surjective onto image), then restrict back to UUU
  • Theorem 4.18. For U⊆R2U \subseteq \R^2U⊆R2 open and Y⊆R3Y \subseteq \R^3Y⊆R3, if σ:U→Y\sigma : U \to Yσ:U→Y is smooth s.t. σu,σv\sigma_u,\sigma_vσu​,σv​ are lin. indep. at (u,v)∈U(u,v) \in U(u,v)∈U, then σ\sigmaσ is a regular chart near (u,v)(u,v)(u,v)
  • Theorem 4.21 (Inverse function theorem). Let U⊆RnU \subseteq \R^nU⊆Rn be open and f:U→Rnf : U \to \R^nf:U→Rn be smooth; if DFDFDF is invertible at x0∈Ux_0 \in Ux0​∈U, then fff has a local inverse (restricts to diffeomorphism) near f(x0)f(x_0)f(x0​)

5. Features of smooth surfaces

  • Theorem 5.1. If Φ=ρ−1∘σ:V→V′\Phi = \rho^{-1} \circ \sigma : V \to V'Φ=ρ−1∘σ:V→V′ is a transition map from σ\sigmaσ to ρ\rhoρ,
    • (i) If σ\sigmaσ is regular on VVV and ρ\rhoρ is regular on V′V'V′, then Φ\PhiΦ is a diffeomorphism
    • (ii) If ρ\rhoρ is regular on V′V'V′ and Φ\PhiΦ is a diffeomorphism, then σ\sigmaσ is regular on VVV
  • Definition 5.2. For a smooth surface SSS and p∈Sp \in Sp∈S, a tangent vector to SSS at ppp is a tangent vector at ppp to a curve on SSS passing through ppp
    • The tangent space TpST_pSTp​S, is the collection of all tangent vectors to SSS at ppp
  • Proposition 5.6. For a smooth surface SSS with regular chart σ:U→S∩W\sigma : U \to S \cap Wσ:U→S∩W and p=σ(u0,v0)∈S∩Wp = \sigma(u_0,v_0) \in S \cap Wp=σ(u0​,v0​)∈S∩W, TpST_pSTp​S is a 2-dimensional vector subspace of R3\R^3R3 with basis σu(u0,v0),σv(u0,v0)\sigma_u(u_0,v_0),\sigma_v(u_0,v_0)σu​(u0​,v0​),σv​(u0​,v0​)
    • Proposition 5.5. A curve δ:I→U\delta : I \to Uδ:I→U with δ(t0)=(u0,v0)\delta(t_0) = (u_0,v_0)δ(t0​)=(u0​,v0​) and δ˙(t0)=(a,b)\dot\delta(t_0) = (a,b)δ˙(t0​)=(a,b) yields a curve γ=σ∘δ:I→S∩W\gamma = \sigma \circ \delta : I \to S \cap Wγ=σ∘δ:I→S∩W s.t. γ(t0)=p\gamma(t_0) = pγ(t0​)=p and γ˙(t0)=aσu(u0,v0)+bσv(u0,v0)\dot\gamma(t_0) = a\sigma_u(u_0,v_0) + b\sigma_v(u_0,v_0)γ˙​(t0​)=aσu​(u0​,v0​)+bσv​(u0​,v0​)
    • I.e. TpS=span⁡{σu(u0,v0),σv(u0,v0)}T_pS = \span\{\sigma_u(u_0,v_0),\sigma_v(u_0,v_0)\}Tp​S=span{σu​(u0​,v0​),σv​(u0​,v0​)}
  • Definition 5.8. The tangent plane to smooth SSS at ppp is p+TpSp + T_pSp+Tp​S, the plane parallel to TpST_pSTp​S passing through ppp

5.4. Normal vectors

  • Definition 5.9. A normal vector to smooth SSS at ppp is a nonzero vector normal to TpST_pSTp​S
    • Set of normal vectors is a 1-dimensional subspace of TpST_pSTp​S
    • At each point, there are two unit normal vectors
  • Proposition 5.10 (Unit normal to chart). For smooth SSS, a regular chart σ:U→S∩W\sigma : U \to S \cap Wσ:U→S∩W, and p∈Up \in Up∈U, a unit normal vector to SSS at ppp is
    N=σu×σv∥σu×σv∥N = \frac{\sigma_u \times \sigma_v}{\norm{\sigma_u \times \sigma_v}}N=∥σu​×σv​∥σu​×σv​​
    • Exercise 25 (Unit normal to graph). If SSS is the graph of a smooth function f:U→Rf : U \to \Rf:U→R, then a unit normal to SSS at (x,y,f(x,y))(x,y,f(x,y))(x,y,f(x,y)) is
      N=(−fx,−fy,1)fx2+fy2+1;N = \frac{(-f_x,-f_y,1)}{\sqrt{f_x^2 + f_y^2 + 1}};N=fx2​+fy2​+1​(−fx​,−fy​,1)​;
      • Then SSS is an oriented surface (as this is smooth and defined on all of SSS)
  • Proposition 5.11. For smooth SSS, the tangent plane to SSS at ppp has equation
    N⋅(v−p)=0N \cdot (v - p) = 0N⋅(v−p)=0
    where NNN is a unit normal vector to SSS at ppp and v=(x,y,z)v = (x,y,z)v=(x,y,z)
  • Proposition 5.13 (Unit normal to level surface). For U⊆R3U \subseteq \R^3U⊆R3 open, f:U→Rf : U \to \Rf:U→R smooth, and S=f−1(c)S = f^{-1}(c)S=f−1(c) for some c∈Rc \in \Rc∈R, if ∇f(p)≠0\nabla f(p) \neq 0∇f(p)=0 for all p∈Sp \in Sp∈S, then
    N=∇f∥∇f∥N = \frac{\nabla f}{\norm{\nabla f}}N=∥∇f∥∇f​
    is a unit normal on SSS
    • NNN is smooth and defined on all of SSS, thus SSS is an oriented surface

5.7. Orientability

  • Definition 5.15. For U⊆RnU \subseteq \R^nU⊆Rn open, F:U→RnF : U \to \R^nF:U→Rn is
    • (i) orientation-preserving at p∈Up \in Up∈U if det⁡DF(p)>0\det DF(p) > 0detDF(p)>0
    • (ii) orientation-reversing if det⁡DF(p)<0\det DF(p) < 0detDF(p)<0
  • Proposition 5.16. Two regular charts for SSS whose images overlap determine the same unit normal iff the transition map Φ\PhiΦ between them is orientation-preserving
  • Proposition 5.17. For smooth SSS, the following are equivalent:
    • (i) SSS has an orientation, i.e. a smooth unit normal vector field
    • (ii) SSS has an atlas of regular charts for which all transition maps are orientation-preserving
  • Definition 5.18. A smooth surface with a smooth unit normal vector field is orientable; it is then an oriented surface

6. Types of surfaces

2. Quadric surfaces

  • Definition 2.1. Let F∈R[x,y,z]F \in \R[\xx,\yy,\zz]F∈R[x,y,z] be a quadratic, and associate it with the map F:R3→RF : \R^3 \to \RF:R3→R.
    • (i) A quadric is a level set of FFF, i.e. F−1(c)F^{-1}(c)F−1(c) for some c∈Rc \in \Rc∈R
    • (ii) A quadric surface is a quadric which is also a surface
  • Standard form of quadratic:
    • F(x,y,z)=ax2+by2+cz2+2dxy+2eyz+2fxz+gx+hy+iz+jF(x,y,z) = ax^2 + by^2 + cz^2 + 2dxy + 2eyz + 2fxz + gx + hy + iz + jF(x,y,z)=ax2+by2+cz2+2dxy+2eyz+2fxz+gx+hy+iz+j
    • F(v)=v⊤Av+B⊤v+CF(v) = v^\top Av + B^\top v + CF(v)=v⊤Av+B⊤v+C where
      v=(x,y,z)⊤,A=(adfdbefec)∈Sym⁡3(R),B=(g,h,i)⊤∈R3,C=j∈Rv = (x,y,z)^\top, \quad A = \begin{pmatrix} a & d & f \\ d & b & e \\ f & e & c \end{pmatrix} \in \operatorname{Sym}_3(\R), \quad B = (g,h,i)^\top \in \R^3, \quad C = j \in \Rv=(x,y,z)⊤,A=⎝⎛​adf​dbe​fec​⎠⎞​∈Sym3​(R),B=(g,h,i)⊤∈R3,C=j∈R

2.4. Simplifying quadrics

  • Proposition 2.20. Let A∈Sym⁡3(R)A \in \operatorname{Sym}_3(\R)A∈Sym3​(R), v1,v2,v3v_1,v_2,v_3v1​,v2​,v3​ is right-handed orthonormal basis of eigenvectors for A, with eigenvalues λ1,λ2,λ3\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\lambda_3λ1​,λ2​,λ3​ respectively
    • Let QQQ be change of basis matrix for standard basis (ei)(e_i)(ei​) to (vi)(v_i)(vi​) (i.e. iiith column of QQQ is viv_ivi​)
    • Then Q∈SO(3)Q \in SO(3)Q∈SO(3) (rotation) and Q⊤AQ=Q−1AQ=D=diag⁡(λ1,λ2,λ3)Q^\top AQ = Q^{-1}AQ = D = \operatorname{diag}(\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\lambda_3)Q⊤AQ=Q−1AQ=D=diag(λ1​,λ2​,λ3​)
      • Equivalently, A=QDQ−1=QDQ⊤A = QDQ^{-1} = QDQ^\topA=QDQ−1=QDQ⊤ is an orthogonal diagonalisation of AAA
      • Always exists since a real symmetric matrix has an orthonormal basis of eigenvectors
  • Proposition 2.21. Let F(v)=v⊤Av+B⊤v+CF(v) = v^\top Av + B^\top v + CF(v)=v⊤Av+B⊤v+C be a quadratic in standard form, V=Q−1v=Q⊤v=(X,Y,Z)⊤V = Q^{-1}v = Q^\top v = (X,Y,Z)^\topV=Q−1v=Q⊤v=(X,Y,Z)⊤; then
    F(v)=V⊤DV+B⊤QV+C=λ1X2+λ2Y2+λ3Z2+(B⊤Q)V+CF(v) = V^\top DV + B^\top QV + C = \lambda_1X^2 + \lambda_2Y^2 + \lambda_3Z^2 + (B^\top Q)V + CF(v)=V⊤DV+B⊤QV+C=λ1​X2+λ2​Y2+λ3​Z2+(B⊤Q)V+C
    where (B⊤Q)V=(B⊤Q)1X+(B⊤Q)2Y+(B⊤Q)3Z(B^\top Q)V = (B^\top Q)_1X + (B^\top Q)_2Y + (B^\top Q)_3Z(B⊤Q)V=(B⊤Q)1​X+(B⊤Q)2​Y+(B⊤Q)3​Z
    • Complete the square to eliminate linear terms with an associated quadratic term, via V↦V′:=V+wV \mapsto V' := V + wV↦V′:=V+w, to obtain quadric H(V′)H(V')H(V′)
      • Then HHH, written in terms of V′V'V′, is now standard (and H(V′)=F(v)H(V') = F(v)H(V′)=F(v))
      • Note: overall FFF maps to HHH via v↦V′=Q⊤v+wv \mapsto V' = Q^\top v + wv↦V′=Q⊤v+w, so the transformation V′↦v=Q(V′−w)V' \mapsto v = Q(V' - w)V′↦v=Q(V′−w) maps HHH to FFF (these are orientation-preserving isometries)

2.7. Menagerie of standard quadrics

  • Theorem 2.25. Any quadric, after applying an orientation-preserving isometry (rotation then transformation) is one of
    • (i) Ellipsoid x2/a2+y2/b2+z2/c2=1x^2/a^2 + y^2/b^2 + z^2/c^2 = 1x2/a2+y2/b2+z2/c2=1
    • (ii) Hyperboloid of one sheet x2/a2+y2/b2−z2/c2=1x^2/a^2 + y^2/b^2 - z^2/c^2 = 1x2/a2+y2/b2−z2/c2=1
    • (iii) Hyperboloid of two sheets x2/a2−y2/b2−z2/c2=1x^2/a^2 - y^2/b^2 - z^2/c^2 = 1x2/a2−y2/b2−z2/c2=1
    • (iv) Elliptic paraboloid x2/a2+y2/b2−z=0x^2/a^2 + y^2/b^2 - z = 0x2/a2+y2/b2−z=0
    • (v) Hyperbolic paraboloid x2/a2−y2/b2−z=0x^2/a^2 - y^2/b^2 - z = 0x2/a2−y2/b2−z=0
    • (vi) Elliptic cone x2/a2+y2/b2−z2/c2=0x^2/a^2 + y^2/b^2 - z^2/c^2 = 0x2/a2+y2/b2−z2/c2=0
    • (vii) Elliptic cylinder x2/a2+y2/b2=1x^2/a^2 + y^2/b^2 = 1x2/a2+y2/b2=1
    • (viii) Hyperbolic cylinder x2/a2−y2/b2=1x^2/a^2 - y^2/b^2 = 1x2/a2−y2/b2=1
    • (ix) Parabolic cylinder x2/a2−y=0x^2/a^2 - y = 0x2/a2−y=0
    • (x) Plane x2/a2=0x^2/a^2 = 0x2/a2=0
    • (xi) Two intersecting planes x2/a2−y2/b2=0x^2/a^2 - y^2/b^2 = 0x2/a2−y2/b2=0
    • (xii) Two parallel planes x2/a2=1x^2/a^2 = 1x2/a2=1
    • (xiii) Straight line x2/a2+y2/b2=0x^2/a^2 + y^2/b^2 = 0x2/a2+y2/b2=0
    • (xiv) Point x2/a2+y2/b2+z2/c2=0x^2/a^2 + y^2/b^2 + z^2/c^2 = 0x2/a2+y2/b2+z2/c2=0
    • (xv) Empty set (sum of squares is negative)
  • Given symmetric matrix AAA describing quadratic terms and (suitably ordered) eigenvalues:
    • If λi=0\lambda_i = 0λi​=0, corresponding variable may appear linearly (L) or not at all (N)
      Sign λ1\lambda_1λ1​ Sign λ2\lambda_2λ2​ Sign λ3\lambda_3λ3​ Constant Possible type
      +++ +++ +++ +++ Ellipsoid
      +++ +++ +++ 000 Point
      +++ +++ +++ −-− Empty set
      +++ +++ −-− +++ Hyperboloid of one sheet
      +++ +++ −-− 000 Elliptic cone
      +++ +++ −-− −-− Hyperboloid of two sheets
      +++ +++ 000 (L) 000 Elliptic paraboloid
      +++ +++ 000 (N) +++ Elliptic cylinder
      +++ +++ 000 (N) 000 Line
      +++ +++ 000 (N) −-− Empty set
      +++ −-− 000 (L) +++ Hyperbolic paraboloid
      +++ −-− 000 (N) +,−+,-+,− Hyperbolic cylinder
      +++ −-− 000 (N) 000 Two intersecting planes
      +++ 000 (L) 000 (N) 000 Parabolic cylinder
      +++ 000 (N) 000 (N) +++ Two parallel planes
      +++ 000 (N) 000 (N) 000 Plane
      +++ 000 (N) 000 (N) −-− Empty set

3. Ruled surfaces

  • Definition 3.1. A ruled surface is a surface that is a disjoint union of straight lines (or line segments), called rulings
    • Coordinate chart for ruled surface:
      • Let γ:I→S\gamma : I \to Sγ:I→S be a curve transverse (not parallel) to the rulings, i.e. γ(u)\gamma(u)γ(u) lies on a ruling LuL_uLu​, with δ:I→R3\delta : I \to \R^3δ:I→R3 s.t. δ(u)\delta(u)δ(u) points along LuL_uLu​

      • Exercise 3 (ch. 8). If γ\gammaγ is unit speed and δ\deltaδ is unit length, then g=(1+v2∥δ˙∥2+2vγ˙⋅δ˙) du2+(γ˙⋅δ) du dv+dv2g = (1 + v^2\norm{\dot\delta}^2 + 2v\dot\gamma \cdot \dot\delta)\,du^2 + (\dot\gamma \cdot \delta)\,du\,dv + dv^2g=(1+v2∥δ˙∥2+2vγ˙​⋅δ˙)du2+(γ˙​⋅δ)dudv+dv2
  • Cylinder over γ\gammaγ: coordinate chart given by (restriction of) σ(u,v)=γ(u)+vδ\sigma(u,v) = \gamma(u) + v\deltaσ(u,v)=γ(u)+vδ
    • assuming σ\sigmaσ is homeomorphism (in particular injective)

4. Surfaces of revolution

  • Definition 4.1. A surface of revolution is a surface obtained by rotating a curve γ\gammaγ in a plane Π\PiΠ around a line LLL in Π\PiΠ
  • If Π\PiΠ is xzxzxz-plane and LLL is zzz-axis, with γ=(f,0,g):I→Π\gamma = (f,0,g) : I \to \Piγ=(f,0,g):I→Π (with I⊆RI \subseteq \RI⊆R open interval), then (a restriction of) σ(u,v)=(f(u)cos⁡v,f(u)sin⁡v,g(u))\sigma(u,v) = (f(u)\cos v,f(u)\sin v,g(u))σ(u,v)=(f(u)cosv,f(u)sinv,g(u)) forms a chart
    • Lemma 4.2. If σ\sigmaσ is a usual chart for a surface for revolution, if γ=(f,0,g)\gamma = (f,0,g)γ=(f,0,g) is regular and f(t)≠0f(t) \neq 0f(t)=0 always, then σ\sigmaσ is regular
      • If γ\gammaγ is simple, restrict σ\sigmaσ to U1=I×(0,2π)U_1 = I \times (0,2\pi)U1​=I×(0,2π) and U2=I×(−π,π)U_2 = I \times (-\pi,\pi)U2​=I×(−π,π) to get charts and thus atlas
      • WLOG can take f>0f > 0f>0; if f<0f < 0f<0, then use γ=(−f,0,h)\gamma = (-f,0,h)γ=(−f,0,h) instead
    • Example 4.7. For a surface of revolution obtained from regular γ=(f,0,h)\gamma = (f,0,h)γ=(f,0,h) by rotation around zzz-axis, E=f˙(u)2+h˙(u)2E = \dot f(u)^2 + \dot h(u)^2E=f˙​(u)2+h˙(u)2, F=0F = 0F=0, G=f(u)2G = f(u)^2G=f(u)2
      • If f>0f > 0f>0, letting U=I×(0,2π)U = I \times (0,2\pi)U=I×(0,2π), we see that area is
        A=∫Uf(u)f˙(u)2+h˙(u)2 du dv\mathcal{A} = \int_U f(u) \sqrt{\dot f(u)^2 + \dot h(u)^2}\,du\,dvA=∫U​f(u)f˙​(u)2+h˙(u)2​dudv
      • Moreover, if γ\gammaγ is unit speed, then
        A=∫Uf(u) du dv\mathcal{A} = \int_U f(u)\,du\,dvA=∫U​f(u)dudv
    • If γ\gammaγ (in xzxzxz-plane) is given by level set f−1(c)f^{-1}(c)f−1(c), i.e. γ(I)={(x,0,z):f(x,z)=c}\gamma(I) = \{(x,0,z) : f(x,z) = c\}γ(I)={(x,0,z):f(x,z)=c}, then surface of revolution has equation
      f(x2+y2,z)=cf\left(\sqrt{x^2 + y^2},z\right) = cf(x2+y2​,z)=c

5. Compact surfaces

  • Defintition 5.1. A set S⊆R3S \subseteq \R^3S⊆R3 is compact if it is closed and bounded
    • If f:U→Rf : U \to \Rf:U→R is continuous (for some U⊆RnU \subseteq \R^nU⊆Rn), then f−1(c)f^{-1}(c)f−1(c) is closed (in UUU) for every c∈Rc \in \Rc∈R (preimage of closed set)
      • If UUU is closed, then f−1(c)f^{-1}(c)f−1(c) is closed in Rn\R^nRn too (properties of subspace topology)
  • Theorem 5.11 (Classification of surfaces). Every compact smooth surface in R3\R^3R3 is diffeomorphic to a genus ggg surface for some ggg
    • It follows that it must be orientable

7. Maps of surfaces

  • Proposition 1.2. Let f:S→S~f : S \to \tilde Sf:S→S~ be a map of surfaces and p∈Sp \in Sp∈S

    • When switching charts, the effect on FFF in coordinates is to compose with a transition map

2. Continuity and smoothness

  • Definition 2.1. A map of surfaces f:S→S~f : S \to \tilde Sf:S→S~ is continuous at p∈Sp \in Sp∈S if for (xn)(x_n)(xn​) in SSS s.t. xn→px_n \to pxn​→p, f(xn)→f(p)f(x_n) \to f(p)f(xn​)→f(p)
  • Lemma 2.3. f:S→S~f : S \to \tilde Sf:S→S~ is continuous at ppp if and only if FFF on coordinates (using appropriate charts (σ,σ~)(\sigma,\tilde\sigma)(σ,σ~) covering p,f(p)p,f(p)p,f(p)) is continuous at σ−1(p)\sigma^{-1}(p)σ−1(p)
    • If fff is continuous at ppp, then domain U′=σ−1(Y∩f−1(Y~))U' = \sigma^{-1}(Y \cap f^{-1}(\tilde Y))U′=σ−1(Y∩f−1(Y~)) of FFF is open nbhd of σ−1(p)\sigma^{-1}(p)σ−1(p)
  • Definition 2.4. Let S,S~S,\tilde SS,S~ be smooth surfaces, and f:S→S~f : S \to \tilde Sf:S→S~ be continuous
    • (i) fff is smooth at a point p∈Sp \in Sp∈S if there are regular charts σ,σ~\sigma,\tilde\sigmaσ,σ~ covering p,f(p)p,f(p)p,f(p) resp. s.t. FFF in coordinates is smooth at σ−1(p)\sigma^{-1}(p)σ−1(p)
    • (ii) fff is smooth if it is smooth at all p∈Sp \in Sp∈S
  • Proposition 2.6. f:S→S~f : S \to \tilde Sf:S→S~ is smooth at p∈Sp \in Sp∈S iff for all regular charts σ,σ~\sigma,\tilde\sigmaσ,σ~ covering p,f(p)p,f(p)p,f(p), σ~−1∘f∘σ\tilde\sigma^{-1} \circ f \circ \sigmaσ~−1∘f∘σ is smooth at σ−1(p)\sigma^{-1}(p)σ−1(p)
  • Definition 2.7. f:S→S~f : S \to \tilde Sf:S→S~ between smooth surfaces is a diffeomorphism if it is smooth, bijective, with smooth inverse
    • Two surfaces are diffeomorphic if there is a diffeomorphism f:S→S~f : S \to \tilde Sf:S→S~
  • Definition 2.8. A local diffeomorphism of surfaces is a map f:S→S~f : S \to \tilde Sf:S→S~ s.t. for all p∈Sp \in Sp∈S, there is a open neighbourhood VVV of ppp on SSS, s.t. f∣V:V→f(V)f|_V : V \to f(V)f∣V​:V→f(V) is a diffeomorphism of surfaces
    • Local diffeomorphisms are continuous
    • There is no surjective local diffeo. from S2S^2S2 to R2\R^2R2 (sphere is compact, plane is not)

  • Proposition 4.9.
    • (i) Let f:S→Sf : S \to Sf:S→S be the identity map and p∈Sp \in Sp∈S; then Dpf:TpS→TpSD_p f : T_pS \to T_pSDp​f:Tp​S→Tp​S is the identity

  • Proposition 4.10. If f:S→S~f : S \to \tilde Sf:S→S~ is smooth, then fff is a local diffeomorphism iff for all p∈Sp \in Sp∈S, DpfD_p fDp​f is invertible

8. Riemannian metric

  • Definition 1.1. The Riemannian metric of SSS at p∈Sp \in Sp∈S is the map
    gp:TpS×TpS→R,(v,w)↦v⋅wg_p : T_pS \times T_pS \to \R, \quad (v,w) \mapsto v \cdot wgp​:Tp​S×Tp​S→R,(v,w)↦v⋅w
    • The Riemannian metric of SSS is the collection of all gpg_pgp​ over SSS
    • Remark 1.2. Riemannian metric is a restriction of the dot product to TpST_pSTp​S
  • Length from Riemannian metric: for v∈TpSv \in T_pSv∈Tp​S, gp(v,v)=∥v∥2g_p(v,v) = \norm{v}^2gp​(v,v)=∥v∥2
  • Angle from Riemannian metric: for v,w∈TpSv,w \in T_pSv,w∈Tp​S, angle θ\thetaθ between them satisfies
    cos⁡θ=gp(v,w)gp(v,v)gp(w,w)\cos\theta = \frac{g_p(v,w)}{\sqrt{g_p(v,v)g_p(w,w)}}cosθ=gp​(v,v)gp​(w,w)​gp​(v,w)​

2. Inner products

  • Definition 2.1. A bilinear form on a vector space VVV is a map k:V×V→Rk : V \times V \to \Rk:V×V→R s.t. for any a,b∈Ra,b \in \Ra,b∈R and u,v,w∈Vu,v,w \in Vu,v,w∈V,
  • (i) k(au+bv,w)=a k(u,w)+b k(v,w)k(au+bv,w) = a\,k(u,w) + b\,k(v,w)k(au+bv,w)=ak(u,w)+bk(v,w)
  • (i) k(u,av+bw)=a k(u,v)+b k(u,w)k(u,av+bw) = a\,k(u,v) + b\,k(u,w)k(u,av+bw)=ak(u,v)+bk(u,w)
  • Definition 2.3. A bilinear form kkk on VVV is symmetric if for all v,w∈Vv,w \in Vv,w∈V, k(v,w)=k(w,v)k(v,w) = k(w,v)k(v,w)=k(w,v)
  • Definition 2.4. A bilinear form kkk on VVV is positive definite if for all v∈Vv \in Vv∈V, k(v,v)≥0k(v,v) \geq 0k(v,v)≥0, with k(v,v)=0k(v,v) = 0k(v,v)=0 iff v=0v = 0v=0
  • Definition 2.6. An inner product on a vector space VVV is a symmetric positive definite bilinear form on VVV
    • E.g. the dot product on Rn\R^nRn
  • Definition 2.14. For an inner product kkk on VVV, the length of v∈Vv \in Vv∈V w.r.t. kkk is ∥v∥k=k(v,v)\norm{v}_k = \sqrt{k(v,v)}∥v∥k​=k(v,v)​
  • Definition 2.15. For an inner product kkk on VVV, the angle between v,w∈Vv,w \in Vv,w∈V w.r.t. kkk is the unique θ∈[0,π]\theta \in [0,\pi]θ∈[0,π] s.t.
    cos⁡θ=k(v,w)k(v,v)k(w,w)\cos\theta = \frac{k(v,w)}{\sqrt{k(v,v)k(w,w)}}cosθ=k(v,v)k(w,w)​k(v,w)​

2.2. Bilinear forms in coordinates

  • Definition 2.7. If kkk is a bilinear form on VVV, the matrix of kkk w.r.t. the ordered basis b=(b1,…,bn)b = (b_1,\dotsc,b_n)b=(b1​,…,bn​) is the n×nn \times nn×n matrix Mk,bM_{k,b}Mk,b​ whose (i,j)(i,j)(i,j)-entry is kij=k(bi,bj)k_{ij} = k(b_i,b_j)kij​=k(bi​,bj​)
    • For the dot product w.r.t. the standard basis, M⋅,e=IM_{\cdot,e} = IM⋅,e​=I
    • If the matrix is diagonal, the basis is orthogonal; if it is III, the basis is orthonormal
  • Proposition 2.10. Let v,w∈Vv,w \in Vv,w∈V and bbb be a basis of VVV; then k(v,w)=vb⊤Mk,bwbk(v,w) = v_b^\top M_{k,b} w_bk(v,w)=vb⊤​Mk,b​wb​
    • vb,wbv_b,w_bvb​,wb​ are coordinates of v,wv,wv,w w.r.t. bbb
  • Proposition 2.13. If kkk is an inner product on VVV and bbb is an ordered basis, then Mk,bM_{k,b}Mk,b​ is symmetric and has all positive eigenvalues
  • Proposition 2.16. Let v∈Vv \in Vv∈V have coordinates v1,…,vnv_1,\dotsc,v_nv1​,…,vn​ w.r.t bbb; then the length of vvv w.r.t. an inner product kkk is
    ∥v∥k2=∑i=1nvi2kii+∑1≤i<j≤n2vivjkij\norm{v}_k^2 = \sum_{i = 1}^n v_i^2 k_{ii} + \sum_{1 \leq i < j \leq n} 2v_iv_j k_{ij}∥v∥k2​=i=1∑n​vi2​kii​+1≤i<j≤n∑​2vi​vj​kij​

3. Riemannian metric as an inner product

  • Lemma 3.1. For p∈Sp \in Sp∈S a smooth surface, gpg_pgp​ is an inner product on TpST_pSTp​S
    • Thus induces a metric on TpST_pSTp​S
    • Also it's enough to know what gpg_pgp​ does on basis vectors (by Proposition 2.10 above)
  • Definition 3.2. If σ\sigmaσ is a regular chart for SSS, we define the coefficients of the Riemannian metric ggg by
    E=g11=g(σu,σu),F=g12=g21=g(σu,σv),G=g22=g(σv,σv)E = g_{11} = g(\sigma_u,\sigma_u), \quad F = g_{12} = g_{21} = g(\sigma_u,\sigma_v), \quad G = g_{22} = g(\sigma_v,\sigma_v)E=g11​=g(σu​,σu​),F=g12​=g21​=g(σu​,σv​),G=g22​=g(σv​,σv​)
    • This is the 2×22 \times 22×2 (symmetric) matrix Mg,σ=gM_{g,\sigma} = gMg,σ​=g of ggg w.r.t basis σ=(σu,σv)\sigma = (\sigma_u,\sigma_v)σ=(σu​,σv​)
    • Matrix of metric is equal to (Dσ)⊤(Dσ)(D\sigma)^\top (D\sigma)(Dσ)⊤(Dσ); if σ\sigmaσ is smooth (not necessarily chart), ∥σu×σv∥2=det⁡((Dσ)⊤(Dσ))=EG−F2>0\norm{\sigma_u \times \sigma_v}^2 = \det((D\sigma)^\top (D\sigma)) = EG - F^2 > 0∥σu​×σv​∥2=det((Dσ)⊤(Dσ))=EG−F2>0 (since regular) from assignment 3 (question 5)
      • So matrix of ggg is (always) invertible
    • For V=V1σu+V2σv,W=W1σu+W2σv∈TpSV = V_1\sigma_u + V_2\sigma_v,W = W_1\sigma_u + W_2\sigma_v \in T_pSV=V1​σu​+V2​σv​,W=W1​σu​+W2​σv​∈Tp​S,
      g(V,W)=V1W1E+V1W2F+V2W1F+V2W2Gg(V,W) = V_1W_1E + V_1W_2F + V_2W_1F + V_2W_2Gg(V,W)=V1​W1​E+V1​W2​F+V2​W1​F+V2​W2​G
      and
      ∥V∥2=g(V,V)=EV12+2FV1V2+GV22\norm{V}^2 = g(V,V) = E V_1^2 + 2F V_1V_2 + G V_2^2∥V∥2=g(V,V)=EV12​+2FV1​V2​+GV22​
  • Definition 3.3. If ggg on regular chart σ\sigmaσ has coefficients E,F,GE,F,GE,F,G as above, then ggg is expressed in differentials as g=E du2+2F du dv+G dv2g = E\,du^2 + 2F\,du\,dv + G\,dv^2g=Edu2+2Fdudv+Gdv2

5. Lengths of curves

  • The length of a regular curve γ:I=(a,b)→S\gamma : I = (a,b) \to Sγ:I=(a,b)→S is
    L(γ)=∫abg(γ˙,γ˙) dtL(\gamma) = \int_a^b \sqrt{g(\dot\gamma,\dot\gamma)}\,dtL(γ)=∫ab​g(γ˙​,γ˙​)​dt
    • If σ\sigmaσ is regular chart covering γ=σ(u,v)\gamma = \sigma(u,v)γ=σ(u,v) (γ,u,v\gamma,u,vγ,u,v functions of ttt),
      g(γ˙,γ˙)=Eu˙2+2Fu˙v˙+Gv˙2,g(\dot\gamma,\dot\gamma) = E\dot u^2 + 2F\dot u\dot v + G\dot v^2,g(γ˙​,γ˙​)=Eu˙2+2Fu˙v˙+Gv˙2,
      so
      L(γ)=∫IE du2+2F du dv+G dv2=∫IgL(\gamma) = \int_I \sqrt{E\,du^2 + 2F\,du\,dv + G\,dv^2} = \int_I \sqrt{g}L(γ)=∫I​Edu2+2Fdudv+Gdv2​=∫I​g​
  • Surface of revolution Riemannian metric examples
    • Example 6.1 (Spherical coordinates). Standard regular chart of S2S^2S2 is σ(u,v)=(cos⁡ucos⁡v,cos⁡usin⁡v,sin⁡u)\sigma(u,v) = (\cos u\cos v,\cos u\sin v,\sin u)σ(u,v)=(cosucosv,cosusinv,sinu), over U1=(−π/2,π/2)×(0,2π)U_1 = (-\pi/2,\pi/2) \times (0,2\pi)U1​=(−π/2,π/2)×(0,2π) and U2=(−π/2,π/2)×(−π,π)U_2 = (-\pi/2,\pi/2) \times (-\pi,\pi)U2​=(−π/2,π/2)×(−π,π)

      • Riemannian metric: E=1E = 1E=1, F=0F = 0F=0, G=cos⁡2uG = \cos^2 uG=cos2u, i.e. g=ds2=du2+cos⁡2u dv2g = ds^2 = du^2 + \cos^2 u \, dv^2g=ds2=du2+cos2udv2
        • σu=(−sin⁡ucos⁡v,−sin⁡usin⁡v,cos⁡u)\sigma_u = (-\sin u\cos v,-\sin u\sin v,\cos u)σu​=(−sinucosv,−sinusinv,cosu) and σv=(−cos⁡usin⁡v,cos⁡ucos⁡v,0)\sigma_v = (-\cos u\sin v,\cos u\cos v,0)σv​=(−cosusinv,cosucosv,0)

8. Area of a surface

  • Proposition 8.3. Let σ\sigmaσ be a regular chart and ggg its Riemannian metric with coefficients E,F,GE,F,GE,F,G; then
    ∥σu×σv∥2=EG−F2\norm{\sigma_u \times \sigma_v}^2 = EG - F^2∥σu​×σv​∥2=EG−F2
  • Definition 8.1. Area of smooth surface SSS with regular chart (atlas) σ:U→S\sigma : U \to Sσ:U→S is given by
    A=∫SdA=∫U∥σu×σv∥ du dv\mathcal{A} = \int_S dA = \int_U \norm{\sigma_u \times \sigma_v}\,du\,dvA=∫S​dA=∫U​∥σu​×σv​∥dudv
    • Equivalently, area is
      A=∫UEG−F2 du dv=∫Udet⁡g du dv\mathcal{A} = \int_U \sqrt{EG - F^2}\,du\,dv = \int_U \sqrt{\det g}\,du\,dvA=∫U​EG−F2​dudv=∫U​detg​dudv
  • Exercise 7. The area of the graph of smooth f:U→Rf : U \to \Rf:U→R (for U⊆R2U \subseteq \R^2U⊆R2 open) is
    A=∫Ufx2+fy2+1 dx dy\mathcal{A} = \int_U \sqrt{f_x^2 + f_y^2 + 1}\,dx\,dyA=∫U​fx2​+fy2​+1​dxdy

9. Geometry-preserving maps

2. Isometries

  • Lemma 2.1. For inner product spaces (V,h)(V,h)(V,h) and (W,k)(W,k)(W,k) and f:V→Wf : V \to Wf:V→W linear, the following are equivalent:
    • (i) fff preserves inner products, i.e. h=f∗kh = f^*kh=f∗k
      • I.e. h(v1,v2)=k(f(v1),f(v2))h(v_1,v_2) = k(f(v_1),f(v_2))h(v1​,v2​)=k(f(v1​),f(v2​)) for v1,v2∈Vv_1,v_2 \in Vv1​,v2​∈V
    • (ii) fff preserves lengths, i.e. h(v,v)=k(f(v).f(v))h(v,v) = k(f(v).f(v))h(v,v)=k(f(v).f(v)) for all v∈Vv \in Vv∈V
    • (Polarisation identity) For v,w∈Vv,w \in Vv,w∈V, h(v,w)=∥v+w∥2−∥v−w∥24h(v,w) = \frac{\norm{v + w}^2 - \norm{v - w}^2}{4}h(v,w)=4∥v+w∥2−∥v−w∥2​
  • Definition 2.2. A linear map f:(V,h)→(W,k)f : (V,h) \to (W,k)f:(V,h)→(W,k) is a (linear) isometry if it preserves inner products (or lengths)
    • Proposition 2.9. A linear map f:(V,h)→(W,k)f : (V,h) \to (W,k)f:(V,h)→(W,k) is an isometry iff h=f∗kh = f^* kh=f∗k
    • Exercise 2. If f:V→Wf : V \to Wf:V→W is a linear isometry, fff is injective; moreover, if dim⁡V=dim⁡W\dim V = \dim WdimV=dimW, then fff is bijective

2.2. Pullbacks of inner products

  • Definition 2.6. For a bilinear form kkk on WWW and a linear map f:V→Wf : V \to Wf:V→W, the pullback f∗kf^*kf∗k of kkk under fff is the map on V×VV \times VV×V given by (v1,v2)↦k(f(v1),f(v2))(v_1,v_2) \mapsto k(f(v_1),f(v_2))(v1​,v2​)↦k(f(v1​),f(v2​))
    • Lemma 2.5. The pullback of kkk under fff is a bilinear form on VVV
  • Lemma 2.7. For an inner product kkk on WWW and a linear map f:V→Wf : V \to Wf:V→W,
    • (i) If kkk is symmetric, then f∗kf^*kf∗k is symmetric
    • (ii) If kkk is positive definite and fff is injective, then f∗kf^*kf∗k is positive definite
  • Lemma 2.8. For an inner product kkk on WWW and an injective linear map f:V→Wf : V \to Wf:V→W, f∗kf^*kf∗k is an inner product on VVV

2.4. Isometries of surfaces

  • Definition 2.10. An isometry of Rn\R^nRn is a function f:Rn→Rnf : \R^n \to \R^nf:Rn→Rn s.t.
    ∥x−y∥=∥f(x)−f(y)∥\norm{x - y} = \norm{f(x) - f(y)}∥x−y∥=∥f(x)−f(y)∥
    for all x,y∈Rnx,y \in \R^nx,y∈Rn
    • This implies fff is continuous, indeed smooth
  • Theorem 2.11.
    • (i) Any orientation-preserving isometry of R2\R^2R2 is a rotation, a translation, or the identity
    • (i) Any orientation-reversing isometry of R2\R^2R2 is a reflection or a glide reflection
  • Theorem 2.12.
    • (i) There is a unique unit speed curve in R2\R^2R2 with prescribed κs:I→R\kappa_s : I \to \Rκs​:I→R, up to (orientation-preserving) isometry of R2\R^2R2 (see Theorem (3)3.11)
    • (i) There is a unique unit speed curve in R3\R^3R3 with prescribed κ,τ:I→R\kappa,\tau : I \to \Rκ,τ:I→R, up to (orientation-preserving) isometry of R3\R^3R3 (see Theorem (3)4.20)
  • Definition 2.13. The map fff is a local isometry at ppp if, for all v,w∈TpSv,w \in T_pSv,w∈Tp​S,
    gp(v,w)=g~f(p)(Dpf(v),Dpf(w))=(f∗g~)p(v,w)g_p(v,w) = \tilde g_{f(p)}(D_pf(v),D_pf(w)) = (f^* \tilde g)_p(v,w)gp​(v,w)=g~​f(p)​(Dp​f(v),Dp​f(w))=(f∗g~​)p​(v,w)
    • If fff is a local isometry at every p∈Sp \in Sp∈S, then it is a local isometry (of surfaces)
    • Definition 2.17. The pullback of g~\tilde gg~​ under fff at ppp is the bilinear form
      (f∗g~)p:=(Dpf)∗g~f(p):TpS×TpS→R(f^*\tilde g)_p := (D_p f)^*\tilde g_{f(p)} : T_pS \times T_pS \to \R(f∗g~​)p​:=(Dp​f)∗g~​f(p)​:Tp​S×Tp​S→R
      • The pullback of g~\tilde gg~​ under fff, denoted f∗g~f^*\tilde gf∗g~​, is the collection of all (f∗g~)p(f^*\tilde g)_p(f∗g~​)p​ over p∈Sp \in Sp∈S
      • Often write f∗vf_*vf∗​v instead of Dpf(v)D_p f(v)Dp​f(v) for pushforward, i.e. f∗=Dpff_* = D_p ff∗​=Dp​f
    • Lemma 2.18. Equivalently fff is a local isometry iff f∗g~=gf^*\tilde g = gf∗g~​=g
  • Lemma 2.14. A smooth map f:S→S~f : S \to \tilde Sf:S→S~ is a local isometry at p∈Sp \in Sp∈S iff DpfD_pfDp​f is a linear isometry of inner product spaces (TpS,gp)↦(Tf(p)S~,g~f(p))(T_pS,g_p) \mapsto (T_{f(p)}\tilde S,\tilde g_{f(p)})(Tp​S,gp​)↦(Tf(p)​S~,g~​f(p)​)
  • Definition 2.16. The smooth map f:S→S~f : S \to \tilde Sf:S→S~ is an isometry if it is a bijective local isometry
    • Two surfaces are isometric if there is an isometry between them
  • Lemma 2.23. For f:S→S~f : S \to \tilde Sf:S→S~ smooth, σ:U→S\sigma : U \to Sσ:U→S regular chart, let ρ:=f∘σ:U→S~\rho := f \circ \sigma : U \to \tilde Sρ:=f∘σ:U→S~; the following are equivalent:
    • (i) fff is a local diffeomorphism
    • (ii) ρu,ρv\rho_u,\rho_vρu​,ρv​ are lin. indep. on UUU
    • (iii) For any (u,v)∈U(u,v) \in U(u,v)∈U, there is an open neighbourhood VVV of (u,v)(u,v)(u,v) (in UUU) s.t. ρ∣V\rho|_Vρ∣V​ is regular chart for S~\tilde SS~
    • (iv) For all (u,v)∈U(u,v) \in U(u,v)∈U, E~(u,v)G~(u,v)−F~(u,v)2≠0\tilde E(u,v)\tilde G(u,v) - \tilde F(u,v)^2 \neq 0E~(u,v)G~(u,v)−F~(u,v)2=0, where E~=ρu⋅ρu\tilde E = \rho_u \cdot \rho_uE~=ρu​⋅ρu​, F~=ρu⋅ρv\tilde F = \rho_u \cdot \rho_vF~=ρu​⋅ρv​, G~=ρv⋅ρv\tilde G = \rho_v \cdot \rho_vG~=ρv​⋅ρv​
  • Proposition 2.24. For f:S→S~f : S \to \tilde Sf:S→S~ smooth, σ:U→S\sigma : U \to Sσ:U→S regular chart, let ρ=f∘σ:U→S~\rho = f \circ \sigma : U \to \tilde Sρ=f∘σ:U→S~
    • Let E,F,GE,F,GE,F,G be coefficients of ggg and E~=ρu⋅ρu\tilde E = \rho_u \cdot \rho_uE~=ρu​⋅ρu​, F~=ρu⋅ρv\tilde F = \rho_u \cdot \rho_vF~=ρu​⋅ρv​, G~=ρv⋅ρv\tilde G = \rho_v \cdot \rho_vG~=ρv​⋅ρv​

2.6. Preserving lengths of curves

  • Definition 2.21. A smooth map f:S→S~f : S \to \tilde Sf:S→S~ preserves lengths of curves if for any regular curve γ\gammaγ, L(γ)=L(f∘γ)L(\gamma) = L(f \circ \gamma)L(γ)=L(f∘γ)
  • Theorem 2.22. A smooth map f:S→S~f : S \to \tilde Sf:S→S~ preserves lengths of curves iff it is a local isometry

3. Conformal maps

  • Definition 3.1. A smooth map f:S→S~f : S \to \tilde Sf:S→S~ is conformal (or preserves angles) if for any regular α,β\alpha,\betaα,β on SSS meeting at ppp, the angle between α,β\alpha,\betaα,β at ppp is the angle between f∘αf \circ \alphaf∘α and f∘βf \circ \betaf∘β at f(p)f(p)f(p)
    • Lemma 3.2. fff is conformal iff for all p∈Sp \in Sp∈S and v,w∈TpSv,w \in T_pSv,w∈Tp​S, the angle b/w v,wv,wv,w is the angle between Dpf(v),Dpf(w)D_pf(v),D_pf(w)Dp​f(v),Dp​f(w)
    • Proposition 3.3. Composition of conformal maps is conformal
    • Proposition 3.4. Local isometries are conformal maps
  • Definition 3.5. The spiral symmetry with factor rrr and angle θ\thetaθ about p∈R2p \in \R^2p∈R2 is the map R2→R2\R^2 \to \R^2R2→R2 given by
    • (i) a dilation by factor rrr from ppp, then
    • (ii) a rotation of angle θ\thetaθ around ppp
    • Lemma 3.6. If r>0r > 0r>0 and p=0p = 0p=0, its matrix is
      (rcos⁡θ−rsin⁡θrsin⁡θrcos⁡θ)\begin{pmatrix} r\cos\theta & -r\sin\theta \\ r\sin\theta & r\cos\theta \end{pmatrix}(rcosθrsinθ​−rsinθrcosθ​)
    • Proposition 3.7. Identifying (x,y)∈R2(x,y) \in \R^2(x,y)∈R2 with x+yi∈Cx + yi \in \Cx+yi∈C, the map C→C\C \to \CC→C, z↦reiθzz \mapsto re^{i\theta}zz↦reiθz is the spiral symmetry with factor rrr and angle θ\thetaθ about the origin
    • Lemma 3.8. For any (a,b)≠0(a,b) \neq 0(a,b)=0, the linear map given by the antisymmetric matrix
      (a−bba)\begin{pmatrix} a & -b \\ b & a \end{pmatrix}(ab​−ba​)
  • Theorem 3.9. For complex differentiable f:C→Cf : \C \to \Cf:C→C, fff is conformal at any z∈Cz \in \Cz∈C with f′(z)≠0f'(z) \neq 0f′(z)=0
  • Theorem 3.10. M∈M2(R)M \in M_2(\R)M∈M2​(R) gives a conformal linear map f:R2→R2f : \R^2 \to \R^2f:R2→R2 iff
    M=(a−bba)or(abb−a)M = \begin{pmatrix} a & -b \\ b & a \end{pmatrix} \quad \text{or} \quad \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ b & -a \end{pmatrix}M=(ab​−ba​)or(ab​b−a​)

  • Theorem 3.12. A map f=(α,β):R2→R2f = (\alpha,\beta) : \R^2 \to \R^2f=(α,β):R2→R2 is conformal iff
    • (i) αx=βy\alpha_x = \beta_yαx​=βy​ and αy=−βx\alpha_y = -\beta_xαy​=−βx​ (orientation-preserving case), or
    • (ii) αy=βx\alpha_y = \beta_xαy​=βx​ and αx=−βy\alpha_x = -\beta_yαx​=−βy​ (orientation-reversing case)

3.10. Conformal inner products

  • Definition 3.13. A linear map f:(V,h)→(W,k)f : (V,h) \to (W,k)f:(V,h)→(W,k) of inner product spaces is conformal if, for all nonzero v1,v2∈Wv_1,v_2 \in Wv1​,v2​∈W,
    h(v1,v2)h(v1,v1)h(v2,v2)=f∗k(v1,v2)f∗k(v1,v1)f∗k(v2,v2)\frac{h(v_1,v_2)}{\sqrt{h(v_1,v_1)h(v_2,v_2)}} = \frac{f^*k(v_1,v_2)}{\sqrt{f^*k(v_1,v_1)f^*k(v_2,v_2)}}h(v1​,v1​)h(v2​,v2​)​h(v1​,v2​)​=f∗k(v1​,v1​)f∗k(v2​,v2​)​f∗k(v1​,v2​)​
  • Definition 3.14. For inner products h,kh,kh,k on VVV, h,kh,kh,k are conformal if, for all nonzero v1,v2∈Wv_1,v_2 \in Wv1​,v2​∈W,
    h(v1,v2)h(v1,v1)h(v2,v2)=k(v1,v2)k(v1,v1)k(v2,v2)\frac{h(v_1,v_2)}{\sqrt{h(v_1,v_1)h(v_2,v_2)}} = \frac{k(v_1,v_2)}{\sqrt{k(v_1,v_1)k(v_2,v_2)}}h(v1​,v1​)h(v2​,v2​)​h(v1​,v2​)​=k(v1​,v1​)k(v2​,v2​)​k(v1​,v2​)​
    • I.e. angle between vectors are equal
  • Lemma 3.15. If for all v1,v2∈Vv_1,v_2 \in Vv1​,v2​∈V, k(v1,v2)=λh(v1,v2)k(v_1,v_2) = \lambda h(v_1,v_2)k(v1​,v2​)=λh(v1​,v2​) for some λ>0\lambda > 0λ>0, then h,kh,kh,k are conformal
  • Proposition 3.16. If h,kh,kh,k are conformal on 2-dimensional VVV, then k=λhk = \lambda hk=λh for some λ>0\lambda > 0λ>0
  • Proposition 3.17. A linear map f:(V,h)→(W,k)f : (V,h) \to (W,k)f:(V,h)→(W,k) is conformal iff f∗k=λhf^* k = \lambda hf∗k=λh for some λ>0\lambda > 0λ>0

        A2=∫UE~G~−F~2 du dv=λ∫UEG−F2 du dv=λA1;\mathcal{A}_2 = \int_U \sqrt{\tilde E\tilde G - \tilde F^2}\,du\,dv = \lambda \int_U \sqrt{EG - F^2}\,du\,dv = \lambda \mathcal{A}_1;A2​=∫U​E~G~−F~2​dudv=λ∫U​EG−F2​dudv=λA1​;
