4. Equiareal maps

  • Definition 4.1. A smooth map f:S→S~f : S \to \tilde Sf:S→S~ is equiareal if it takes any sufficiently small subsurface S′S'S′ of SSS, to a subsurface of S~\tilde SS~ of the same area
  • Proposition 4.2. For f:S→S~f : S \to \tilde Sf:S→S~ smooth, σ:U→S\sigma : U \to Sσ:U→S regular chart, let ρ=f∘σ:U→S~\rho = f \circ \sigma : U \to \tilde Sρ=f∘σ:U→S~
    • Let E,F,GE,F,GE,F,G be coefficients of ggg and E~=ρu⋅ρu\tilde E = \rho_u \cdot \rho_uE~=ρu​⋅ρu​, F~=ρu⋅ρv\tilde F = \rho_u \cdot \rho_vF~=ρu​⋅ρv​, G~=ρv⋅ρv\tilde G = \rho_v \cdot \rho_vG~=ρv​⋅ρv​
    • Then fff is equiareal iff EG−F2=E~G~−F~2EG - F^2 = \tilde E\tilde G - \tilde F^2EG−F2=E~G~−F~2
  • Example (Archimedes' map is conformal). f:S→Cf : S \to Cf:S→C (unit sphere minus poles to unit cylinder) projecting radially outwards:
    f(x,y,z)=(xx2+y2,yx2+y2,z)f(x,y,z) = \left(\frac{x}{\sqrt{x^2 + y^2}},\frac{y}{\sqrt{x^2 + y^2}},z\right)f(x,y,z)=(x2+y2​x​,x2+y2​y​,z)

5. Summary of geometry-preserving maps

  • Local diffeomorphisms preserve (local) differential structure
  • Local isometries preserve distances (and lengths of curves)
  • Conformal maps preserve angles
  • Equiareal maps preserve areas
  • For f:S→S~f : S \to \tilde Sf:S→S~ smooth, σ:U→S\sigma : U \to Sσ:U→S regular chart, let ρ=f∘σ:U→S~\rho = f \circ \sigma : U \to \tilde Sρ=f∘σ:U→S~
    • Let E,F,GE,F,GE,F,G be coefficients of ggg and E~=ρu⋅ρu\tilde E = \rho_u \cdot \rho_uE~=ρu​⋅ρu​, F~=ρu⋅ρv\tilde F = \rho_u \cdot \rho_vF~=ρu​⋅ρv​, G~=ρv⋅ρv\tilde G = \rho_v \cdot \rho_vG~=ρv​⋅ρv​
    • (Proposition 2.24.) fff is a local isometry iff (E,F,G)=(E~,F~,G~)(E,F,G) = (\tilde E,\tilde F,\tilde G)(E,F,G)=(E~,F~,G~) (or g=f∗g~g = f^*\tilde gg=f∗g~​)
    • (Proposition 3.19.) fff is conformal iff (E,F,G)=λ(E~,F~,G~)(E,F,G) = \lambda(\tilde E,\tilde F,\tilde G)(E,F,G)=λ(E~,F~,G~) (or g=λf∗g~g = \lambda f^*\tilde gg=λf∗g~​) for some λ:S→R+\lambda : S \to \R^+λ:S→R+
    • (Proposition 4.2.) fff is equiareal iff EG−F2=E~G~−F~2EG - F^2 = \tilde E\tilde G - \tilde F^2EG−F2=E~G~−F~2
  • Local isometry/conformal/equiareal   ⟹  \implies⟹ local diffeomorphism
  • Conformal + equiareal   ⟺  \iff⟺ local isometry

10. Second fundamental form

3. Gauss and Weingarten maps

  • Definition 2.1. The second fundamental form of SSS (with unit normal N\mathbf NN) w.r.t. regular σ\sigmaσ is k=L du2+2M du dv+N dv2k = L\,du^2 + 2M\,du\,dv + N\,dv^2k=Ldu2+2Mdudv+Ndv2, where L=σuu⋅NL = \sigma_{uu} \cdot \mathbf NL=σuu​⋅N, M=σuv⋅NM = \sigma_{uv} \cdot \mathbf NM=σuv​⋅N, and L=σvv⋅NL = \sigma_{vv} \cdot \mathbf NL=σvv​⋅N
  • Definition 3.1. For smooth oriented SSS with normal vector field N\mathbf NN, the Gauss map is G:S→S2\mathcal G : S \to S^2G:S→S2, p↦N(p)∈S2p \mapsto \mathbf N(p) \in S^2p↦N(p)∈S2
    • Remark 3.3. Based at origin (for G\mathcal GG) instead of at ppp (for N\mathbf NN)
    • Remark 3.5. G\mathcal GG is smooth map of surfaces
    • Often write Gu=Nu\mathcal G_u = \mathbf N_uGu​=Nu​ (note DpG(σu)=NuD_p\mathcal G(\sigma_u) = \mathbf N_uDp​G(σu​)=Nu​), Gv=Nv\mathcal G_v = \mathbf N_vGv​=Nv​ (note DpG(σv)=NvD_p\mathcal G(\sigma_v) = \mathbf N_vDp​G(σv​)=Nv​)
  • Definition 4.1. The Weingarten map (or shape operator) of smooth SSS at p∈Sp \in Sp∈S is Wp=−DpG:TpS→TG(p)S2=TpS\mathcal{W}_p = -D_p \mathcal{G} : T_pS \to T_{\mathcal{G}(p)}S^2 = T_p SWp​=−Dp​G:Tp​S→TG(p)​S2=Tp​S
  • Proposition 4.6. For regular σ\sigmaσ, σu⋅Nu=−L\sigma_u \cdot \mathbf N_u = -Lσu​⋅Nu​=−L, σu⋅Nv=σv⋅Nu=−M\sigma_u \cdot \mathbf N_v = \sigma_v \cdot \mathbf N_u = -Mσu​⋅Nv​=σv​⋅Nu​=−M, and σv⋅Nv=−N\sigma_v \cdot \mathbf N_v = -Nσv​⋅Nv​=−N
  • Theorem 4.7. For regular σ\sigmaσ, w.r.t. basis {σu,σv}\{\sigma_u,\sigma_v\}{σu​,σv​} of TpST_pSTp​S, the Weingarten map has matrix Wp=g−1k\mathcal W_p = g^{-1}kWp​=g−1k (matrices of Riemannian matrix and second fundamental forms of σ\sigmaσ)
  • Proposition 4.10. For regular σ\sigmaσ, w.r.t. basis {σu,σv}\{\sigma_u,\sigma_v\}{σu​,σv​} of TpST_pSTp​S, the derivative of the Gauss map is given by
    DpG=1EG−F2(FM−GLFN−GMFL−EMFM−EN)D_p\mathcal G = \frac{1}{EG - F^2}\begin{pmatrix} FM - GL & FN - GM \\ FL - EM & FM - EN \end{pmatrix}Dp​G=EG−F21​(FM−GLFL−EM​FN−GMFM−EN​)
  • Proposition 4.11 (Weingarten equations).
    Nu=FM−GLEG−F2σu+FL−EMEG−F2σvandNv=FN−GMEG−F2σu+FM−ENEG−F2σv\mathbf N_u = \frac{FM - GL}{EG - F^2}\sigma_u + \frac{FL - EM}{EG - F^2}\sigma_v \quad\text{and}\quad \mathbf N_v = \frac{FN - GM}{EG - F^2}\sigma_u + \frac{FM - EN}{EG - F^2}\sigma_vNu​=EG−F2FM−GL​σu​+EG−F2FL−EM​σv​andNv​=EG−F2FN−GM​σu​+EG−F2FM−EN​σv​
    • These are columns of DpGD_p \mathcal GDp​G

5. Second fundamental form

  • Definition 5.1. Let SSS be smooth with Riemannian metric ggg; then at p∈Sp \in Sp∈S, the second fundamental form is the bilinear form k:TpS×TpS→Rk : T_pS \times T_pS \to \Rk:Tp​S×Tp​S→R, given by kp(v,w)=gp(Wp(v),w)k_p(v,w) = g_p(\mathcal W_p(v),w)kp​(v,w)=gp​(Wp​(v),w)
    • Alternative definition of second fundamental form
    • Proposition 5.4. The definitions are equivalent: k(σu,σu)=Lk(\sigma_u,\sigma_u) = Lk(σu​,σu​)=L, k(σu,σv)=k(σv,σu)=Mk(\sigma_u,\sigma_v) = k(\sigma_v,\sigma_u) = Mk(σu​,σv​)=k(σv​,σu​)=M, and k(σv,σv)=Nk(\sigma_v,\sigma_v) = Nk(σv​,σv​)=N
  • Proposition 5.5. The second fundamental form kkk is symmetric
    • It is not necessarily positive definite

B. Summary of fundamental forms

2. Riemannian metric

  • Bilinear form (inner product) g=gp:TpS×TpS→Rg = g_p : T_pS \times T_pS \to \Rg=gp​:Tp​S×Tp​S→R, (v,w)↦v⋅w(v,w) \mapsto v \cdot w(v,w)↦v⋅w
  • Coefficients E=σu⋅σuE = \sigma_u \cdot \sigma_uE=σu​⋅σu​, F=σu⋅σvF = \sigma_u \cdot \sigma_vF=σu​⋅σv​, G=σv⋅σvG = \sigma_v \cdot \sigma_vG=σv​⋅σv​
  • Written as matrix
    g=(EFFG)g = \begin{pmatrix} E & F \\ F & G \end{pmatrix}g=(EF​FG​)
    • If w1=λ1σu+μ1σvw_1 = \lambda_1\sigma_u + \mu_1\sigma_vw1​=λ1​σu​+μ1​σv​ and w2=λ2σu+μ2σvw_2 = \lambda_2\sigma_u + \mu_2\sigma_vw2​=λ2​σu​+μ2​σv​, then
      g(w1,w2)=(λ1μ1)(EFFG)(λ2μ2)=w1⊤gw2g(w_1,w_2) = \begin{pmatrix} \lambda_1 & \mu_1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} E & F \\ F & G \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} \lambda_2 \\ \mu_2 \end{pmatrix} = w_1^\top g w_2g(w1​,w2​)=(λ1​​μ1​​)(EF​FG​)(λ2​μ2​​)=w1⊤​gw2​
  • Written as differential g=E du2+2F du dv+G dv2g = E\,du^2 + 2F\,du\,dv + G\,dv^2g=Edu2+2Fdudv+Gdv2 (used in finding arclength)

3. Second fundamental form

  • (Definition 5.1, Proposition 5.5.) Symmetric bilinear form k=kp:TpS×TpS→Rk = k_p : T_pS \times T_pS \to \Rk=kp​:Tp​S×Tp​S→R, (v,w)↦g(W(v),w)=W(v)⋅w(v,w) \mapsto g(\mathcal{W}(v),w) = \mathcal{W}(v) \cdot w(v,w)↦g(W(v),w)=W(v)⋅w
    • (Definition 3.1.) Gauss map G:S→S2\mathcal{G} : S \to S^2G:S→S2, p↦N(p)p \mapsto \mathbf{N}(p)p↦N(p) (unit normal to SSS)
    • (Definition 4.1.) Weingarten map Wp=−DpG:TpS→TG(p)S2=TpS\mathcal{W}_p = -D_p \mathcal{G} : T_pS \to T_{\mathcal{G}(p)}S^2 = T_p SWp​=−Dp​G:Tp​S→TG(p)​S2=Tp​S
      • (Theorem 4.7.) Written as matrix W=g−1k\mathcal{W} = g^{-1}kW=g−1k
  • (Proposition 5.4.) Coefficients L=k(σu,σu)L = k(\sigma_u,\sigma_u)L=k(σu​,σu​), M=k(σu,σv)=k(σv,σu)M = k(\sigma_u,\sigma_v) = k(\sigma_v,\sigma_u)M=k(σu​,σv​)=k(σv​,σu​), N=k(σv,σv)N = k(\sigma_v,\sigma_v)N=k(σv​,σv​)
    • (Definition 2.1.) L=σuu⋅NL = \sigma_{uu} \cdot \mathbf{N}L=σuu​⋅N, M=σuv⋅NM = \sigma_{uv} \cdot \mathbf{N}M=σuv​⋅N, G=σvv⋅NG = \sigma_{vv} \cdot \mathbf{N}G=σvv​⋅N (components in unit normal direction N:S→R3\mathbf{N} : S \to \R^3N:S→R3)
    • (Proposition 4.6.) Also letting ρ=N∘σ:U→R3\rho = \mathbf{N} \circ \sigma : U \to \R^3ρ=N∘σ:U→R3, we have L=−σu⋅ρuL = -\sigma_u \cdot \rho_uL=−σu​⋅ρu​, M=−σu⋅ρv=−σv⋅ρuM = -\sigma_u \cdot \rho_v = -\sigma_v \cdot \rho_uM=−σu​⋅ρv​=−σv​⋅ρu​, and N=−σv⋅ρvN = -\sigma_v \cdot \rho_vN=−σv​⋅ρv​
  • Written as matrix
    k=(LMMN)k = \begin{pmatrix} L & M \\ M & N \end{pmatrix}k=(LM​MN​)
    • If w1=λ1σu+μ1σvw_1 = \lambda_1\sigma_u + \mu_1\sigma_vw1​=λ1​σu​+μ1​σv​ and w2=λ2σu+μ2σvw_2 = \lambda_2\sigma_u + \mu_2\sigma_vw2​=λ2​σu​+μ2​σv​, then
      k(w1,w2)=(λ1μ1)(LMMN)(λ2μ2)=w1⊤kw2k(w_1,w_2) = \begin{pmatrix} \lambda_1 & \mu_1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} L & M \\ M & N \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} \lambda_2 \\ \mu_2 \end{pmatrix} = w_1^\top k w_2k(w1​,w2​)=(λ1​​μ1​​)(LM​MN​)(λ2​μ2​​)=w1⊤​kw2​
  • Written as differential k=L du2+2M du dv+N dv2k = L\,du^2 + 2M\,du\,dv + N\,dv^2k=Ldu2+2Mdudv+Ndv2
  • Norm (squared) of vectors w.r.t. kkk is related to normal curvature
    • If vvv is unit vector, k(v,v)k(v,v)k(v,v) is normal curvature of unit speed curve in direction vvv (at ppp)
    • Generally, normal curvature of regular curve is given by k(v,v)/g(v,v)k(v,v)/g(v,v)k(v,v)/g(v,v), so
      κn=L du2+2M du dv+N dv2E du2+2F du dv+G dv2\kappa_n = \frac{L\,du^2 + 2M\,du\,dv + N\,dv^2}{E\,du^2 + 2F\,du\,dv + G\,dv^2}κn​=Edu2+2Fdudv+Gdv2Ldu2+2Mdudv+Ndv2​

11. Curvatures of a surface

2. Gaussian, mean, and principal curvatures

  • Definition 2.1. Let Wp\mathcal{W}_pWp​ be the matrix for the Weingarten map w.r.t. basis σu,σv\sigma_u,\sigma_vσu​,σv​ for TpST_pSTp​S
    • (a) Gaussian curvature of SSS at ppp is K=det⁡WpK = \det\mathcal{W}_pK=detWp​
    • (b) Mean curvature of SSS at ppp is H=12tr⁡WpH = \frac{1}{2}\tr\mathcal{W}_pH=21​trWp​
    • (c) Principal vectors/directions of SSS at ppp are eigenvectors t1,t2\mathbf{t}_1,\mathbf{t}_2t1​,t2​ of Wp\mathcal{W}_pWp​
    • (d) Principal curvatures of SSS at ppp are corresponding eigenvalues κ1,κ2\kappa_1,\kappa_2κ1​,κ2​ of Wp\mathcal{W}_pWp​
  • Exercise 1. Let σ,σ~:U,U~→S\sigma,\tilde\sigma : U,\tilde U \to Sσ,σ~:U,U~→S be regular charts with transition map Φ\PhiΦ (so σ=σ~∘Φ\sigma = \tilde\sigma \circ \Phiσ=σ~∘Φ), and let ρ=N∘σ:U→R3\rho = \mathbf{N} \circ \sigma : U \to \R^3ρ=N∘σ:U→R3 (where N:S→R3\mathbf{N} : S \to \R^3N:S→R3 is unit normal to SSS)
    • (i) g=(Dσ)⊤Dσg = (D\sigma)^\top D\sigmag=(Dσ)⊤Dσ and g=(DΦ)⊤g~(DΦ)g = (D\Phi)^\top\tilde{g}(D\Phi)g=(DΦ)⊤g~​(DΦ)
    • (ii) k=(Dσ)⊤(Dρ)k = (D\sigma)^\top(D\rho)k=(Dσ)⊤(Dρ) and k=(DΦ)⊤k~(DΦ)k = (D\Phi)^\top\tilde{k}(D\Phi)k=(DΦ)⊤k~(DΦ)
    • (iii) W=(DΦ)−1W~(DΦ)\mathcal{W} = (D\Phi)^{-1}\tilde{\mathcal W}(D\Phi)W=(DΦ)−1W~(DΦ), i.e. W\mathcal{W}W and W~\tilde{\mathcal W}W~ are conjugate matrices
    • (iv) So K,H,t1,t2,κ1,κ2K,H,\mathbf{t}_1,\mathbf{t}_2,\kappa_1,\kappa_2K,H,t1​,t2​,κ1​,κ2​ are independent of coordinate chart
  • Proposition 2.7. K=κ1κ2K = \kappa_1\kappa_2K=κ1​κ2​ and H=12(κ1+κ2)H = \frac{1}{2}(\kappa_1 + \kappa_2)H=21​(κ1​+κ2​)
  • Proposition 2.9.
    K=det⁡kdet⁡g=LN−M2EG−F2andH=GL−2FM+EN2(EG−F2)K = \frac{\det k}{\det g} = \frac{LN - M^2}{EG - F^2} \quad\text{and}\quad H = \frac{GL - 2FM + EN}{2(EG - F^2)}K=detgdetk​=EG−F2LN−M2​andH=2(EG−F2)GL−2FM+EN​

3. Curvature of curves on smooth surfaces

  • For γ:I→S\gamma : I \to Sγ:I→S unit speed, there is a left-handed orthonormal basis (γ˙,N,N×γ˙)(\dot\gamma,\mathbf{N},\mathbf{N} \times \dot\gamma)(γ˙​,N,N×γ˙​) at each point (don't require κ≠0\kappa \neq 0κ=0)
  • Definition 3.1. For unit speed γ:I→S\gamma : I \to Sγ:I→S (smooth), writing
    γ¨=κnN+κg(N×γ˙),\ddot\gamma = \kappa_n\mathbf{N} + \kappa_g(\mathbf{N} \times \dot\gamma),γ¨​=κn​N+κg​(N×γ˙​),
    κn\kappa_nκn​ is the normal curvature and κg\kappa_gκg​ is the geodesic curvature of γ\gammaγ
    • A geodesic is a constant speed curve with κg=0\kappa_g = 0κg​=0
    • Remark 3.4. If SSS is xyxyxy-plane (identified with R2\R^2R2), and γ\gammaγ is unit speed along SSS, then κs=κg\kappa_s = \kappa_gκs​=κg​ (signed curvature in R2\R^2R2)
  • Proposition 3.5. For unit speed γ\gammaγ on SSS, κ2=κn2+κg2\kappa^2 = \kappa_n^2 + \kappa_g^2κ2=κn2​+κg2​
    • If κ=0\kappa = 0κ=0 then κn=κg=0\kappa_n = \kappa_g = 0κn​=κg​=0
  • Proposition 3.6. For unit speed γ\gammaγ on SSS, κn=γ¨⋅N\kappa_n = \ddot\gamma \cdot \mathbf Nκn​=γ¨​⋅N and κg=γ¨⋅(N×γ˙)\kappa_g = \ddot\gamma \cdot (\mathbf N \times \dot\gamma)κg​=γ¨​⋅(N×γ˙​)
  • Lemma 3.7. If γ\gammaγ is unit speed and ψ\psiψ is angle between N,γ¨\mathbf N,\ddot\gammaN,γ¨​, then κn=κcos⁡ψ\kappa_n = \kappa\cos\psiκn​=κcosψ and κg=±κsin⁡ψ\kappa_g = \pm\kappa\sin\psiκg​=±κsinψ
    • Remark 3.8. Traversing a curve γ\gammaγ in both directions, one will give κg=κsin⁡ψ\kappa_g = \kappa\sin\psiκg​=κsinψ, and the other κg=−κsin⁡ψ\kappa_g = -\kappa\sin\psiκg​=−κsinψ
  • Proposition 3.10. For unit speed γ\gammaγ on SSS, the normal curvature is given by κn=k(γ˙,γ˙)\kappa_n = k(\dot\gamma,\dot\gamma)κn​=k(γ˙​,γ˙​)

4. Understanding Gaussian curvature

  • Proposition 4.4. If σ\sigmaσ is regular chart for SSS with unit normal N\mathbf NN, then Nu×Nv=Kσu×σv\mathbf N_u \times \mathbf N_v = K\sigma_u \times \sigma_vNu​×Nv​=Kσu​×σv​
    • Remark 4.5. ∥Nu×Nv∥=∣K∣∥σu×σv∥\lVert\mathbf N_u \times \mathbf N_v\rVert = |K|\lVert\sigma_u \times \sigma_v\rVert∥Nu​×Nv​∥=∣K∣∥σu​×σv​∥, i.e. G\mathcal GG infinitesimally expands area by a factor of ∣K∣|K|∣K∣
    • Remark 4.6. G\mathcal GG preserves/reverses orientation accordingly as KKK is positive or negative
  • Definition 4.7. For smooth SSS with Gaussian curvature KKK, the total (Gaussian) curvature of SSS is ∫SK dA\int_S K\,dA∫S​KdA
    • ∫SK dA=(Area covered by G on S+)−(Area covered by G on S−)\int_S K\,dA = (\text{Area covered by}\ \mathcal G\ \text{on}\ S_+) - (\text{Area covered by}\ \mathcal G\ \text{on}\ S_-)∫S​KdA=(Area covered by G on S+​)−(Area covered by G on S−​) where S+={K>0},S−={K<0}S_+ = \{K > 0\},S_- = \{K < 0\}S+​={K>0},S−​={K<0} are where G\mathcal GG preserves/reverses orientation
    • The "signed" area covered by the Gauss map is the total Gaussian curvature
  • Theorem 4.9. Let σ\sigmaσ be regular chart for SSS, let τ=G∘σ\tau = \mathcal G \circ \sigmaτ=G∘σ, and let RδR_\deltaRδ​ be a ball of radius δ\deltaδ around (u0,v0)∈U(u_0,v_0) \in U(u0​,v0​)∈U; then
    lim⁡δ→0A(τ(Rδ))A(σ(Rδ))=∣K∣\lim_{\delta \to 0} \frac{\mathcal A(\tau(R_\delta))}{\mathcal A(\sigma(R_\delta))} = |K|δ→0lim​A(σ(Rδ​))A(τ(Rδ​))​=∣K∣

12. Covariant differentiation, parallel transport, and geodesics

2. Covariant differentiation

  • Definition 2.3. Let γ\gammaγ be regular on SSS, and WWW be a tangent vector field to SSS (along γ\gammaγ); the covariant derivative ∇γW\nabla_\gamma W∇γ​W of WWW along γ\gammaγ is the projection of W˙\dot WW˙ onto the tangent plane Tγ(t)ST_{\gamma(t)}STγ(t)​S at each point γ(t)\gamma(t)γ(t) on γ\gammaγ
    • Remark 2.4. Only need WWW defined along γ\gammaγ
  • Proposition 2.6. For WWW tangent to SSS along γ\gammaγ, ∇γW=W˙−(W˙⋅N)N\nabla_\gamma W = \dot W - (\dot W \cdot \mathbf N)\mathbf N∇γ​W=W˙−(W˙⋅N)N
  • Definition 2.7. Covariant derivative of WWW at ppp in direction of V∈TpSV \in T_pSV∈Tp​S is ∇VW=∇γW\nabla_V W = \nabla_\gamma W∇V​W=∇γ​W, where γ\gammaγ is regular on SSS passing through ppp with velocity VVV
  • Example 2.10. For unit sphere with usual chart and unit vector fields N=σu\mathcal N = \sigma_uN=σu​ and E=σvcos⁡u\mathcal E = \frac{\sigma_v}{\cos u}E=cosuσv​​
    • Along equator γ\gammaγ (unit speed), ∇γN=∇γE=0\nabla_\gamma\mathcal N = \nabla_\gamma\mathcal E = 0∇γ​N=∇γ​E=0 (both are parallel)
    • Along 45∘45^\circ45∘ latitude γ\gammaγ (unit speed), ∇γN=−Eand∇γE=N\nabla_\gamma\mathcal N = -\mathcal E \quad\text{and}\quad \nabla_\gamma\mathcal E = \mathcal N∇γ​N=−Eand∇γ​E=N (neither are parallel)

  • Definition 2.11. The components Γijk\Gamma_{ij}^kΓijk​ of σuu,σuv,σvv\sigma_{uu},\sigma_{uv},\sigma_{vv}σuu​,σuv​,σvv​ in the σu,σv\sigma_u,\sigma_vσu​,σv​ directions are Christoffel symbols
    • Systematically: σij=Γij1σ1+Γij2σ2+kijN\sigma_{ij} = \Gamma_{ij}^1\sigma_1 + \Gamma_{ij}^2\sigma_2 + k_{ij}\mathbf Nσij​=Γij1​σ1​+Γij2​σ2​+kij​N, where σ1=σu\sigma_1 = \sigma_uσ1​=σu​, σ2=σv\sigma_2 = \sigma_vσ2​=σv​, and kij=k(σi,σj)k_{ij} = k(\sigma_i,\sigma_j)kij​=k(σi​,σj​)

3. Parallel transport

  • Definition 3.1. A vector field WWW s.t. ∇γW=0\nabla_\gamma W = 0∇γ​W=0 is parallel or covariant constant along γ\gammaγ
  • Proposition 3.3. WWW is parallel along γ\gammaγ iff W˙\dot WW˙ is always normal to SSS
  • Propostion 3.5 (Parallel vector field equations). W=W1σu+W2σvW = W_1\sigma_u + W_2\sigma_vW=W1​σu​+W2​σv​ is parallel along γ=σ(u,v)\gamma = \sigma(u,v)γ=σ(u,v) iff for k=1,2k = 1,2k=1,2 (both),
    W˙k+W1(u˙Γ11k+v˙Γ12k)+W2(u˙Γ21k+v˙Γ22k)=0\dot W_k + W_1(\dot u\Gamma_{11}^k + \dot v\Gamma_{12}^k) + W_2(\dot u\Gamma_{21}^k + \dot v\Gamma_{22}^k) = 0W˙k​+W1​(u˙Γ11k​+v˙Γ12k​)+W2​(u˙Γ21k​+v˙Γ22k​)=0

  • Definition 3.10.   • Proposition 3.12. The parallel transport map Πγp,q:TpS→TqS\Pi_\gamma^{p,q} : T_pS \to T_qSΠγp,q​:Tp​S→Tq​S from p=γ(t0)p = \gamma(t_0)p=γ(t0​) to q=γ(t1)q = \gamma(t_1)q=γ(t1​) along γ\gammaγ is linear

  • Proposition 3.15. The parallel transport map Πγp,q\Pi_\gamma^{p,q}Πγp,q​ is an isometry of inner product spaces, i.e. (Πγp,q)∗gq=gp(\Pi_\gamma^{p,q})^*g_q = g_p(Πγp,q​)∗gq​=gp​
    • Lemma 3.14. For V,WV,WV,W parallel along regular γ\gammaγ, V⋅WV \cdot WV⋅W is constant

4. Geodesics

  • Definition 4.1. A regular curve γ\gammaγ on SSS is a geodesic if γ˙\dot\gammaγ˙​ is parallel along γ\gammaγ (i.e. ∇γγ˙=0\nabla_\gamma \dot\gamma = 0∇γ​γ˙​=0)
  • Proposition 4.3. γ\gammaγ is a geodesic iff γ¨\ddot\gammaγ¨​ is normal to SSS
  • Proposition 4.4. A geodesic γ\gammaγ has constant speed
  • Proposition 4.5. A regular curve γ\gammaγ on SSS is a geodesic iff it is a constant speed curve with κg=0\kappa_g = 0κg​=0 (equivalence of definitions)
  • Proposition 4.7. A straight line, traversed at constant speed, on any surface, is a geodesic
    • A straight line that is not traversed at constant speed is not a geodesic

4.3. Normal sections

  • Definition 4.11. A plane Π\PiΠ is perpendicular to SSS at p∈Π∩Sp \in \Pi \cap Sp∈Π∩S if NS\mathbf N_SNS​ and NΠ\mathbf N_\PiNΠ​ (unit normals) are perpendicular at ppp
    • The following are equivalent: (i) NS,NΠ\mathbf N_S,\mathbf N_\PiNS​,NΠ​ are perpendicular at ppp; (ii) NS\mathbf N_SNS​ is tangent to Π\PiΠ at ppp; (iii) NΠ\mathbf N_\PiNΠ​ is tangent to SSS at ppp
  • Definition 4.12. For smooth SSS,
    • (i) A normal plane to SSS is a plane Π\PiΠ s.t. for all p∈S∩Πp \in S \cap \Pip∈S∩Π, Π\PiΠ is perpendicular to SSS
    • (ii) A normal section of SSS is S∩ΠS \cap \PiS∩Π where Π\PiΠ is a normal plane
    • Exercise 11. S∩ΠS \cap \PiS∩Π is a collection of curves (Tp(S∩Π)T_p(S \cap \Pi)Tp​(S∩Π) is one-dimensional)
  • Proposition 4.13. A unit speed param. of a normal section is a geodesic
    • The geodesics on the sphere are precisely the great circles

4.4. Geodesic equations

  • Theorem 4.16 (Geodesic equations). A regular curve γ=σ(u1,u2)\gamma = \sigma(u^1,u^2)γ=σ(u1,u2) on SSS is a geodesic iff for i=1,2i = 1,2i=1,2 (both), u¨i+∑j=12∑k=12u˙ju˙kΓjki=0\ddot u^i + \sum_{j = 1}^2\sum_{k=1}^2\dot u^j\dot u^k\Gamma_{jk}^i = 0u¨i+∑j=12​∑k=12​u˙ju˙kΓjki​=0
  • Theorem 4.18 (Geodesic equations, v2). A regular curve γ=σ(u,v)\gamma = \sigma(u,v)γ=σ(u,v) on SSS is a geodesic iff both
    (Eu˙+Fv˙)˙=12(Euu˙2+2Fuu˙v˙+Guv˙2)(E\dot u + F\dot v)\dot{} = \frac{1}{2}(E_u\dot u^2 + 2F_u\dot u\dot v + G_u\dot v^2)(Eu˙+Fv˙)˙=21​(Eu​u˙2+2Fu​u˙v˙+Gu​v˙2)
    (Fu˙+Gv˙)˙=12(Evu˙2+2Fvu˙v˙+Gvv˙2)(F\dot u + G\dot v)\dot{} = \frac{1}{2}(E_v\dot u^2 + 2F_v\dot u\dot v + G_v\dot v^2)(Fu˙+Gv˙)˙=21​(Ev​u˙2+2Fv​u˙v˙+Gv​v˙2)
  • Proposition 4.20. If f:S→S~f : S \to \tilde Sf:S→S~ is a local isometry and γ\gammaγ is a geodesic on SSS, then f∘γf \circ \gammaf∘γ is a geodesic on S~\tilde SS~
  • Theorem 4.23. Let v∈TpSv \in T_pSv∈Tp​S; then there is a unique geodesic on SSS starting at ppp with velocity vvv

13. Two big theorems

2. Egregious theorem

  • (Intrinsic vs extrinsic quantities.) For a smooth surface SSS (intrinsic means derivable from E,F,GE,F,GE,F,G):
    • Intrinsic: Riemannian metric ggg, Gaussian curvature KKK, covariant differentiation ∇γ\nabla_\gamma∇γ​, Christoffel symbols Γijk\Gamma^k_{ij}Γijk​
    • Extrinsic: second fundamental form kkk, Gauss map G\mathcal GG, Weingarten map W\mathcal WW, mean curvature HHH, principal curvatures κi\kappa_iκi​
  • (Dependence on choice of chart.) If σ,σ~\sigma,\tilde\sigmaσ,σ~ are regular charts for SSS with transition map Φ\PhiΦ (so σ(u,v)=σ~(Φ(u,v))\sigma(u,v) = \tilde\sigma(\Phi(u,v))σ(u,v)=σ~(Φ(u,v))), then:
    • g=(DΦ)⊤g~(DΦ)g = (D\Phi)^\top\tilde g(D\Phi)g=(DΦ)⊤g~​(DΦ) (congruent; not generally same)
    • k=(DΦ)⊤k~(DΦ)k = (D\Phi)^\top\tilde k(D\Phi)k=(DΦ)⊤k~(DΦ) (congruent; not generally same)
    • W=(DΦ)−1W~(DΦ)\mathcal W = (D\Phi)^{-1}\tilde{\mathcal W}(D\Phi)W=(DΦ)−1W~(DΦ) (conjugate; not generally same)
    • K=K~K = \tilde KK=K~, H=H~H = \tilde HH=H~, κi=κ~i\kappa_i = \tilde\kappa_iκi​=κ~i​ (same at corresponding points)
  • Theorem 2.2 (Egregious theorem). Local isometries preserve Gaussian curvature
    • I.e. if f:S→S~f : S \to \tilde Sf:S→S~ is a local isometry, then for p∈Sp \in Sp∈S, KS(p)=KS~(f(p))K_S(p) = K_{\tilde S}(f(p))KS​(p)=KS~​(f(p))
    • Corollary 2.3. If S,S~S,\tilde SS,S~ have different values for their Gaussian curvature, there is no local isometry between SSS and S~\tilde SS~
      • I.e. for p∈S,q∈S~p \in S,q \in \tilde Sp∈S,q∈S~ with K(p)≠K~(q)K(p) \neq \tilde K(q)K(p)=K~(q), there is no local isometry f:Up→Uqf : U_p \to U_qf:Up​→Uq​ of neighbourhoods with f(p)=qf(p) = qf(p)=q
    • Example 2.4. Since KΠ=0K_\Pi = 0KΠ​=0 and KS=1/r2K_S = 1/r^2KS​=1/r2 for SSS a sphere of radius rrr, there is no local isometry between (any patches of) Π\PiΠ and SSS
    • Example 2.5. Different radius spheres are not isometric (even locally)
  • Theorem 2.7. For SSS with Riemannian metric ggg (coeffs E,F,GE,F,GE,F,G),
    K=1(EG−F2)2(det⁡(−12Guu+Fuv−12Evv12EuFu−12EvFu−12GuEF12GvFG)−det⁡(012Ev12Gu12EvEF12GuFG))K = \frac{1}{(EG - F^2)^2}\left(\det\begin{pmatrix} -\frac{1}{2}G_{uu} + F_{uv} - \frac{1}{2}E_{vv} & \frac{1}{2}E_u & F_u - \frac{1}{2}E_v \\ F_u - \frac{1}{2}G_u & E & F \\ \frac{1}{2}G_v & F & G \end{pmatrix} - \det\begin{pmatrix} 0 & \frac{1}{2}E_v & \frac{1}{2}G_u \\ \frac{1}{2}E_v & E & F \\ \frac{1}{2}G_u & F & G \end{pmatrix}\right)K=(EG−F2)21​⎝⎛​det⎝⎛​−21​Guu​+Fuv​−21​Evv​Fu​−21​Gu​21​Gv​​21​Eu​EF​Fu​−21​Ev​FG​⎠⎞​−det⎝⎛​021​Ev​21​Gu​​21​Ev​EF​21​Gu​FG​⎠⎞​⎠⎞​
    • Lemma 2.8. For any a,b,c,d,e,f,g,h,i,A,B,C,D,G∈Ra,b,c,d,e,f,g,h,i,A,B,C,D,G \in \Ra,b,c,d,e,f,g,h,i,A,B,C,D,G∈R,
      det⁡(abcdefghi)−det⁡(ABCDefGhi)=det⁡(a−Abcdefghi)−det⁡(0BCDefGhi)\det\begin{pmatrix} a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i \end{pmatrix} - \det\begin{pmatrix} A & B & C \\ D & e & f \\ G & h & i \end{pmatrix} = \det\begin{pmatrix} a - A & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i \end{pmatrix} - \det\begin{pmatrix} 0 & B & C \\ D & e & f \\ G & h & i \end{pmatrix}det⎝⎛​adg​beh​cfi​⎠⎞​−det⎝⎛​ADG​Beh​Cfi​⎠⎞​=det⎝⎛​a−Adg​beh​cfi​⎠⎞​−det⎝⎛​0DG​Beh​Cfi​⎠⎞​
    • Proposition 2.9. For any a,b,c∈R3a,b,c \in \R^3a,b,c∈R3, written as column vectors,
      a⋅(b×c)=det⁡(—a⊤——b⊤——c⊤—)=det⁡(∣∣∣abc∣∣∣)a \cdot (b \times c) = \det\begin{pmatrix} \text{---} & a^\top & \text{---} \\ \text{---} & b^\top & \text{---} \\ \text{---} & c^\top & \text{---} \end{pmatrix} = \det\begin{pmatrix} \vert & \vert & \vert \\ a & b & c \\ \vert & \vert & \vert \end{pmatrix}a⋅(b×c)=det⎝⎛​———​a⊤b⊤c⊤​———​⎠⎞​=det⎝⎛​∣a∣​∣b∣​∣c∣​⎠⎞​
  • Theorem 2.10. Let σ,ρ:U→R3\sigma,\rho : U \to \R^3σ,ρ:U→R3 be regular charts with same g,kg,kg,k and images S,S~S,\tilde SS,S~, then there is an isometry fff of R3\R^3R3 taking SSS to S~\tilde SS~, i.e. f(σ(u,v))=ρ(u,v)f(\sigma(u,v)) = \rho(u,v)f(σ(u,v))=ρ(u,v)

3. Gauss-Bonnet theorem

  • Definition 3.1. The Euler characteristic χ(S)\chi(S)χ(S) of a smooth compact surface SSS in R3\R^3R3 is χ(S)=2−2g\chi(S) = 2 - 2gχ(S)=2−2g, where ggg is the genus of SSS (number of holes/handles)
  • Theorem 3.9. For a compact smooth surface, a polygonal decomposition of SSS consists of a finite set V\mathcal VV of vertices (points of SSS), a finite set E\mathcal EE of edges (regular curves on SSS), such that
    • (i) Each edge begins and ends at a vertex, and does not intersect any vertices
    • (ii) Edges do not self-intersect or intersect each other except at vertices
    • (iii) Each component of S∖(V∪E)S \setminus (\mathcal V \cup \mathcal E)S∖(V∪E), called a face, is homeomorphic to an open disk
  • Theorem 3.10 (Euler's theorem). For any polygonal decomposition of a smooth compact surface SSS with VVV vertices, EEE edges, and FFF faces, V−E+F=χ(S)V - E + F = \chi(S)V−E+F=χ(S)
    • Theorem 3.7. For any polyhedron, V−E+F=2V - E + F = 2V−E+F=2
    • Theorem 3.8. For any plane graph, V−E+F=2V - E + F = 2V−E+F=2
  • Theorem 3.2 (Gauss-Bonnet theorem). For a smooth compact surface, ∫SK dA=2πχ(S)\int_S K\,dA = 2\pi\chi(S)∫S​KdA=2πχ(S)
    • Proposition 3.11. There is a finite atlas of regular charts σi:Ui→Yi\sigma_i : U_i \to Y_iσi​:Ui​→Yi​ and a polygonal decomposition of SSS with FFF faces R1,...,RFR_1,...,R_FR1​,...,RF​, such that:
      • (i) Each face RiR_iRi​ lies in image YiY_iYi​ of σi\sigma_iσi​
      • (ii) Each chart σ\sigmaσ is compatible with the unit normal, N\mathbf NN
      • (iii) The domain UiU_iUi​ of each chart is homeomorphic to an open disc
      • Proposition 3.12. On image of each σ:U→Y\sigma : U \to Yσ:U→Y, there are tangent vector fields e,fe,fe,f which are orthonormal and s.t. e×f=Ne \times f = \mathbf Ne×f=N
      • Proposition 3.13. If γ\gammaγ is unit speed and γ˙=(cos⁡θ)e+(sin⁡θ)f\dot\gamma = (\cos\theta)e + (\sin\theta)fγ˙​=(cosθ)e+(sinθ)f, then κg=θ˙−f˙⋅e\kappa_g = \dot\theta - \dot f \cdot eκg​=θ˙−f˙​⋅e
      • Proposition 3.14. ∇γf=(f˙⋅e)e\nabla_\gamma f = (\dot f \cdot e)e∇γ​f=(f˙​⋅e)e and ∇γe=(e˙⋅f)f\nabla_\gamma e = (\dot e \cdot f)f∇γ​e=(e˙⋅f)f
        • Thus f˙⋅e\dot f \cdot ef˙​⋅e (or e˙⋅f\dot e \cdot fe˙⋅f) measures how much e,fe,fe,f turn as you proceed along γ\gammaγ
    • Definition 3.15. For a unit speed simple closed curve γ\gammaγ in YYY with γ=σ∘β\gamma = \sigma \circ \betaγ=σ∘β,
      • (i) The interior Int⁡(γ)\Int(\gamma)Int(γ) of γ\gammaγ is σ(Int⁡(β))\sigma(\Int(\beta))σ(Int(β))
      • (ii) γ\gammaγ is positively oriented if N×γ˙\mathbf N \times \dot\gammaN×γ˙​ points into Int⁡(γ)\Int(\gamma)Int(γ); otherwise it is negatively oriented
    • Proposition 3.16 (Generalised Umlaufsatz). For positively oriented unit speed simple closed curve γ\gammaγ in YYY,
      ∫γθ˙ ds=2π\int_\gamma \dot\theta\,ds = 2\pi∫γ​θ˙ds=2π
      • Proposition 3.17. For positively oriented unit speed simple closed curve γ\gammaγ in YYY,
        ∫γf˙⋅e ds=∫γ(∇γf)⋅e ds=∫Int⁡(γ)K dA\int_\gamma \dot f \cdot e\,ds = \int_\gamma (\nabla_\gamma f) \cdot e\,ds = \int_{\Int(\gamma)} K\,dA∫γ​f˙​⋅eds=∫γ​(∇γ​f)⋅eds=∫Int(γ)​KdA
    • Theorem 3.21 (Green's theorem). Let f,g:W→Rf,g : W \to \Rf,g:W→R be smooth (where W⊆R2W \subseteq \R^2W⊆R2 is open), and α:R→W\alpha : \R \to Wα:R→W be a positively oriented simple closed curve with Int⁡(α)⊆W\Int(\alpha) \subseteq WInt(α)⊆W; then
      ∫Int⁡(α)(gx−fy) dx dy=∮αf dx+g dy\int_{\Int(\alpha)}(g_x - f_y)\,dx\,dy = \oint_\alpha f\,dx + g\,dy∫Int(α)​(gx​−fy​)dxdy=∮α​fdx+gdy
    • Theorem 3.22 (Gauss-Bonnet for simple closed curves). For positively oriented unit speed simple closed γ\gammaγ in image YYY of single chart σ\sigmaσ, where YYY is homeo. to a disc, then
      ∫γκg ds=2π−∫Int⁡(γ)K dA\int_\gamma \kappa_g\,ds = 2\pi - \int_{\Int(\gamma)} K\,dA∫γ​κg​ds=2π−∫Int(γ)​KdA
      • Example 3.23. On the plane, this reduces to the Umlaufsatz, since κg=κs\kappa_g = \kappa_sκg​=κs​ and K=0K = 0K=0
      • Example 3.24. On the unit sphere, considering the equator γ\gammaγ (at unit speed; a geodesic) which bounds the northern hemisphere RRR, we have 0=2π−∫RdA0 = 2\pi - \int_R dA0=2π−∫R​dA
    • Definition 3.25. A curve with corners in Rn\R^nRn is a curve γ:[a,b]→Rn\gamma : [a,b] \to \R^nγ:[a,b]→Rn s.t.
      • (i) [a,b][a,b][a,b] splits into subintervals at points a=s0<s1<⋯<sn=ba = s_0 < s_1 < \dotsb < s_n = ba=s0​<s1​<⋯<sn​=b
      • (ii) On each subinterval (si,si+1)(s_i,s_{i+1})(si​,si+1​), γ\gammaγ is regular
      • (iii) At each sis_isi​, all one-sided derivatives exist
      • An interior angle of α\alphaα of γ\gammaγ is the angle between two adjacent subcurves
    • Theorem 3.26 (Gauss-Bonnet for simple closed curves with corners). For positively oriented unit speed simple closed γ\gammaγ with corners (with interior angles α1,...,αn\alpha_1,...,\alpha_nα1​,...,αn​) in image YYY of single chart σ\sigmaσ, where YYY is homeo. to a disc, then
      ∫γκg ds=∑i=1nαi−(n−2)π−∫Int⁡(γ)K dA\int_\gamma \kappa_g\,ds = \sum_{i=1}^n \alpha_i - (n - 2)\pi - \int_{\Int(\gamma)} K\,dA∫γ​κg​ds=i=1∑n​αi​−(n−2)π−∫Int(γ)​KdA
    • If the edges of γ\gammaγ are geodesics, then γ\gammaγ is a geodesic polygon
    • Corollary 3.27. If γ\gammaγ is a geodesic polygon (enclosing FFF) with interior angles α1,...,αn\alpha_1,...,\alpha_nα1​,...,αn​, then
      ∫FK dA=∑i=1nαi−(n−2)π\int_F K\,dA = \sum_{i=1}^n \alpha_i - (n - 2)\pi∫F​KdA=i=1∑n​αi​−(n−2)π
    • On the plane, for a straight-line polygon with interior angles α1,...,αn\alpha_1,...,\alpha_nα1​,...,αn​, ∑i=1nαi=(n−2)π\sum_{i=1}^n \alpha_i = (n - 2)\pi∑i=1n​αi​=(n−2)π
    • Corollary 3.28. The area A\mathcal AA of a geodesic triangle on the unit sphere with angles α,β,γ\alpha,\beta,\gammaα,β,γ is A=α+β+γ−π\mathcal A = \alpha + \beta + \gamma - \piA=α+β+γ−π
      • The area A\mathcal AA of a geodesic nnn-gon on the unit sphere with angles αi\alpha_iαi​ is A=∑i=1nαi−(n−2)π\mathcal A = \sum_{i=1}^n \alpha_i - (n - 2)\piA=∑i=1n​αi​−(n−2)π

C. Common surface examples

Additionally, recall that:

  • If σ~=λσ\tilde\sigma = \lambda\sigmaσ~=λσ (where σ,σ~\sigma,\tilde\sigmaσ,σ~ charts for S,S~S,\tilde SS,S~; λ∈R\lambda \in \Rλ∈R), then
    • N~=N\tilde{\mathbf N} = \mathbf NN~=N (so G~=G\tilde{\mathcal G} = \mathcal GG~​=G)
    • g~=λ2g\tilde g = \lambda^2 gg~​=λ2g
    • k~=λk\tilde k = \lambda kk~=λk
    • W~=λ−1W\tilde{\mathcal W} = \lambda^{-1}\mathcal WW~=λ−1W
    • K~=K/λ2\tilde K = K/\lambda^2K~=K/λ2
    • H~=H/λ\tilde H = H/\lambdaH~=H/λ
    • κ~i=κi/λ\tilde\kappa_i = \kappa_i/\lambdaκ~i​=κi​/λ with t~i=ti\tilde{\mathbf t}_i = \mathbf t_it~i​=ti​
  • Wp=−DpG\mathcal W_p = -D_p\mathcal GWp​=−Dp​G
  • H=12tr⁡WpH = \frac{1}{2}\tr\mathcal W_pH=21​trWp​
  • κ1,κ2\kappa_1,\kappa_2κ1​,κ2​ are eigenvalues of Wp\mathcal W_pWp​ (with eigenvectors t1,t2\mathbf t_1,\mathbf t_2t1​,t2​)

Useful formulas:

  • cosh⁡x=(ex+e−x)/2\cosh x = (e^x + e^{-x})/2coshx=(ex+e−x)/2; cosh⁡′=sinh⁡\cosh' = \sinhcosh′=sinh
  • sinh⁡x=(ex−e−x)/2\sinh x = (e^x - e^{-x})/2sinhx=(ex−e−x)/2; sinh⁡′=cosh⁡\sinh' = \coshsinh′=cosh
  • tanh⁡x=sinh⁡x/cosh⁡x=(ex−e−x)/(ex+e−x)\tanh x = \sinh x/\cosh x = (e^x - e^{-x})/(e^x + e^{-x})tanhx=sinhx/coshx=(ex−e−x)/(ex+e−x); tanh⁡′=sech⁡2\tanh' = \operatorname{sech}^2tanh′=sech2
  • sech⁡x=1/cosh⁡x=2/(ex+e−x)\operatorname{sech} x = 1/\cosh x = 2/(e^x + e^{-x})sechx=1/coshx=2/(ex+e−x); sech⁡′=−tanh⁡⋅sech⁡\operatorname{sech}' = -\tanh \cdot \operatorname{sech}sech′=−tanh⋅sech
  • cosh⁡2x−sinh⁡2x=1\cosh^2 x - \sinh^2 x = 1cosh2x−sinh2x=1 and 1−tanh⁡2x=sech⁡2x1 - \tanh^2 x = \operatorname{sech}^2 x1−tanh2x=sech2x
